questions.text: A patient presented with recurrent Raynaud’s phenomenon. She also complained of thickening of skin in the hands and difficulty in swallowing. What is the diagnosis and immunofluorescence pattern shown? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Anti-centromere pattern; Systemic sclerosis

 

The combination of Raynaud's phenomenon, skin thickening limited to hands (acral areas), and difficulty swallowing points to limited systemic sclerosis (formerly called CREST syndrome). The immunofluorescence image shows a characteristic centromeric pattern with discrete speckles corresponding to centromeres in dividing cells. Anti-centromere antibodies are specifically associated with limited systemic sclerosis, making this pattern diagnostic in this clinical context.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nuclear pattern; SLE: Incorrect. The pattern shown is centromeric, not nuclear.

 

Option B. Homogeneous pattern; SLE: Incorrect. Homogeneous patterns are produced by anti-histone and anti-dsDNA antibodies, seen in SLE or drug-induced lupus.

 

Option C. Speckled pattern; Systemic sclerosis: Incorrect. While speckled patterns can be seen in systemic sclerosis (particularly with anti-Scl-70 antibodies in diffuse disease), the image shows a centromeric pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-centromere antibodies producing a centromeric immunofluorescence pattern are specifically associated with limited systemic sclerosis, particularly when presenting with Raynaud's phenomenon and acral skin thickening.

questions.text:
Organize the subsequent structures in the auditory pathway, beginning from the receptors and moving towards the cortex: (INICET May 2023)

 

  1. Auditory Cortex
  2. Spiral ganglion
  3. Cochlear Nucleus
  4. Lateral leminiscus
  5. Inferior colliculus
  6. Olivary complex
  7. Medial geniculate body
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2-3-6-4-5-7-1

 

The correct sequence of structures in the auditory pathway, beginning from the receptors (cochlea) and moving towards the auditory cortex, is as follows:

 

2. Spiral ganglion: The auditory nerve fibers originate here.

 

3. Cochlear Nucleus: The auditory nerve fibers synapse in the cochlear nuclei located in the brainstem.

 

6. Olivary complex: After the cochlear nucleus, the pathway proceeds to the superior olivary complex.

 

4. Lateral lemniscus: From the superior olivary complex, the auditory signals travel via the lateral lemniscus.

 

5. Inferior colliculus: The lateral lemniscus projects to the inferior colliculus in the midbrain.

 

7. Medial geniculate body: The signals are then relayed to the medial geniculate body of the thalamus.

 

1. Auditory Cortex: Finally, the signals reach the auditory cortex (Area 41) in the temporal lobe for processing.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

AUDITORY PATHWAY

 

E – Eighth nerve

 

C – Cochlear nucleus

 

O – Olivary complex (superior)

 

L – Lateral lemniscus

 

I – Inferior colliculus

 

M – Medial geniculate body

 

A – Auditory cortex

questions.text: Which of the following anti-tubercular drug is not bactericidal? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Thioacetazone

 

Thioacetazone is a bacteriostatic anti-tubercular drug. Bacteriostatic drugs inhibit the growth and replication of bacteria, rather than killing them outright. Thioacetazone is less commonly used nowadays due to its side effects and the availability of more effective treatments.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Isoniazid: Isoniazid is a bactericidal drug against actively dividing Mycobacterium tuberculosis bacteria. It works by inhibiting the synthesis of mycolic acid, a critical component of the bacterial cell wall.

 

Option B. Rifapentin: Rifapentin is a bactericidal antibiotic and is a derivative of rifampicin. It works by inhibiting bacterial RNA synthesis and is used primarily in the treatment of tuberculosis.

 

Option D. Kanamycin: Kanamycin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic and is bactericidal. It works by inhibiting bacterial protein synthesis. It is used as a second-line drug for the treatment of multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thioacetazone is a bacteriostatic anti-tubercular drug, which means it inhibits bacterial growth rather than killing the bacteria outright. In contrast, isoniazid, rifapentin, and kanamycin are all bactericidal drugs used in the treatment of tuberculosis.

questions.text: The below-given image is characteristically seen in which of the following type of leprosy? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Borderline leprosy (BB Leprosy)

 

The given image shows a case of borderline leprosy, or dimorphous leprosy, as evidenced by the inverted saucer shaped cutaneous lesions on the patient's skin.

 

Key Characteristics of Borderline Leprosy

 

  • Lesions: Borderline leprosy often presents with numerous skin lesions which may be macular (flat), papular (raised), or annular (ring-shaped) with less defined borders compared to tuberculoid leprosy. The lesions can sometimes exhibit an "inverted saucer" appearance, where the center appears slightly depressed.
  • Symmetry: The lesions tend to be asymmetrical.
  • Sensory Loss: These lesions usually show some sensory loss, although not as pronounced as in tuberculoid leprosy.
  • Reactivity: Borderline leprosy is particularly unstable immunologically, prone to reactivations and shifts toward either more or less severe forms, depending on immune changes in the individual.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Borderline Tuberculoid Leprosy: Closer to the tuberculoid pole with fewer, well-defined lesions and significant nerve involvement.

 

Option B. Lepromatous Leprosy: At the opposite pole from tuberculoid leprosy, characterized by numerous lesions including nodules and plaques, with a high bacterial load but minimal sensory loss.

 

Option D. Histoid Leprosy: A rare variant of lepromatous leprosy presenting as nodules and plaques, often occurring in patients who have experienced leprosy treatment or relapse.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Patients with borderline leprosy are at risk for developing reactions like Type 1 (reversal) reactions, which can lead to rapid worsening of lesions and require immediate medical attention.
  • Accurate diagnosis based on clinical presentation, bacterial index, and histopathology is crucial as the treatment duration and regimen may differ based on the type of leprosy. Borderline leprosy is typically treated with multi-drug therapy (MDT), similar to other forms of leprosy.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of Dermatology 9th edition page no 28.3, 28.5, 28.10

questions.text:
The fibres of the internal oblique muscle and transversus abdominus muscle contribute to which boundaries of the inguinal canal walls? (INICET Nov 2023)

 

  1. Anterior wall
  2. Roof
  3. Floor
  4. Posterior wall
questions.solution:
Ans. A) ii and iv

 

 

 

The inguinal canal is an important structure in the anterior abdominal wall, with specific boundaries formed by different layers of muscles and fascia. The internal oblique is present in the lateral 1/3rd of anterior wall but transverse abdominis does not contribute to the anterior wall at all.

 

ii. Roof: The fibres of the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles, along with their conjoint tendon, form the roof of the inguinal canal.

 

iv. Posterior wall: The conjoint tendon, formed by the joining of the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles, also contributes to the posterior wall of the inguinal canal.

 

Other Options:

 

i. Anterior wall: The anterior wall of the inguinal canal is primarily formed by the external oblique aponeurosis, along with skin and superficial fascia. The internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles do not contribute to the anterior wall.

 

iii. Floor: The floor of the inguinal canal is formed by the inguinal ligament, not by the internal oblique or transversus abdominis muscles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles contribute to the roof and posterior wall of the inguinal canal through their conjoint tendon.

questions.text: Identify the factor 'L' which combines with tissue factor to activate factor IX in given coagulation cascade? (AIIMS MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Factor VII

 

The factor marked as 'L' is factor VII, which combines with tissue factor to activate factor IX.

 

 

Thrombin also activates factor XIlI, which is the fibrin stabilizing factor to factor XIlla. This factor XIlla forms covalent cross-links and thereby stabilizes the fibrin clot.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Factor XII: Involved in the initiation of the intrinsic pathway, but it does not combine with tissue factor.

 

Option C. Factor VIII: Works as a cofactor for Factor IXa in the intrinsic pathway, but it does not combine with tissue factor.

 

Option D. VWF (Von Willebrand Factor): Involved in platelet adhesion and stabilization of Factor VIII but is not involved in the activation of the coagulation cascade by tissue factor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Factor VII is the key clotting factor that combines with tissue factor to activate Factor IX and Factor X, playing a crucial role in the extrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade.

questions.text: A patient is unable to abduct his arm. Which of the following root values is likely to be affected? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. C5

 

Explanation:

 

The most likely cause of the inability to abduct the arm is a C5 root lesion.

 

The C5 spinal nerve plays a crucial role in controlling shoulder abduction. It gives rise to the axillary nerve, which innervates the deltoid muscle. Damage or compression of the C5 nerve root or axillary nerve can result in weakness or paralysis of the deltoid muscle, leading to difficulty in abducting the arm.

 

Deltoid is supplied by axillary nerve which has the root value of C4-C6. The C5 component is responsible for abduction.Other components help in flexion and extensionm at shoulder joint

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. C4: The C4 spinal nerve does not directly innervate the muscles responsible for shoulder abduction. It primarily supplies sensory information to areas of the neck and upper shoulders.

 

Option C. C6: The C6 spinal nerve primarily innervates the muscles responsible for elbow flexion and wrist extension, not shoulder abduction. Damage to the C6 nerve root would affect these functions rather than shoulder abduction.

 

Option D. C7: The C7 spinal nerve primarily innervates the muscles responsible for elbow and wrist flexion and finger extension. It is not directly involved in shoulder abduction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Muscles of the shoulder

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is not transmitted by the vector shown below? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Orientia

 

Explanation:

 

Orientia, the causative agent of scrub typhus, is transmitted by chigger mites, not by the tick shown in the image.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Babesia: Transmitted by ticks

 

Option C. Ehrlichia: Also transmitted by ticks

 

Option D. Crimean congo hemorrhagic fever : Also transmitted by ticks

 

Educational Objective:

 

Orientia tsutsugamushi, responsible for scrub typhus, is not transmitted by ticks but by chigger mites, distinguishing it from other tick-borne infections like Babesia and Ehrlichia.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy, a known case of type I DM, undergoes the following test for the detection of KB. Which is this test: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rothera's Test

 

The test used for the detection of ketone bodies (KB) in the given scenario of a 15-year-old boy with type I diabetes mellitus is Rothera's Test.

 

Rothera's Test involves the reaction of acetoacetate with sodium nitroprusside and glycine in an alkaline medium. This reaction forms a purple-colored complex, indicating the presence of ketone bodies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Benedict's test is used to detect the presence of reducing sugars, such as glucose, in a solution.

 

Option C. Seliwanoff's test is used to differentiate between different types of sugars, particularly distinguishing ketoses from aldoses.

 

Option D. Biuret test The Biuret test is used to detect the presence of proteins in a sample by reacting with peptide bonds.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rothera's Test is a commonly used laboratory test to detect the presence of ketone bodies, specifically acetoacetate, in urine or blood samples. It is particularly relevant in the context of diabetes mellitus, as individuals with uncontrolled diabetes, especially type I diabetes, may experience an increase in ketone production.

 

In type I diabetes, the body is unable to produce sufficient insulin, resulting in a lack of glucose utilization by cells for energy. As a result, the body begins to break down fats as an alternative energy source, leading to the production of ketone bodies, including acetoacetate.

choices.text: Carbon monoxide poisoning

questions.text: Identify the left curve, given the fact that the right curve is of adult hemoglobin.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Myoglobin

 

Explanation

 

  • The left curve is for myoglobin as it is a rectangular hyperbola curve which is characteristic of Michaelis Menton kinetics.
  • Fetal hemoglobin, CO poisoning and acidosis will shift the sigmoidal shape of hemoglobin saturation curve as shown in the image below:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fetal hemoglobin: Fetal hemoglobin has a higher affinity for oxygen than adult hemoglobin, which shifts the curve to the left. However, the curve still maintains a sigmoidal shape.

 

Option C. Carbon monoxide poisoning: Carbon monoxide binds to hemoglobin with a much higher affinity than oxygen, shifting the hemoglobin dissociation curve to the left and making it more difficult for oxygen to be released to tissues. This also retains the sigmoidal shape.

 

Option D. Acidosis: Acidosis generally causes a rightward shift of the hemoglobin oxygen dissociation curve, reducing hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen. This is the opposite of what is observed with myoglobin.

The left shift observed in the myoglobin curve reflects its high affinity for oxygen, distinguishing it from the sigmoidal curves seen in hemoglobin variations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myoglobin has a hyperbolic oxygen dissociation curve due to its single polypeptide chain and high oxygen affinity, contrasting with the sigmoidal curve of hemoglobin due to its cooperative binding.

questions.text: A psychotic patient developed voluntary purposeless movements and was once observed to be standing still for hours with waxy flexibility and negativism. What is the appropriate medical management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lorazepam

 

The patient's presentation suggests catatonia, which can manifest with features like waxy flexibility, negativism, and purposeless movements.

 

Lorazepam is a first-line treatment for catatonia. It often provides rapid relief of symptoms.

 

Other Options :

 

Option A. Haloperidol is an antipsychotic that can be used in psychotic disorders, but it is not the first-line treatment for catatonia. Additionally, antipsychotics might exacerbate or even induce catatonia.

 

Option C. Clonidine and Option D. Propranolol are not used as primary treatments for catatonia.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Catatonia is a neuropsychiatric syndrome that can manifest with features like waxy flexibility, negativism, and purposeless movements. Lorazepam is a first-line treatment for catatonia and can provide rapid symptom relief. ECT is considered to be the treatment of choice.

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 59, 67.

questions.text: Which of the following STD is transmitted by all components of the blood?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Syphilis

 

Syphilis is a sexually transmitted disease (STD) caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum. It can be transmitted through various means, including sexual contact, from mother to child during childbirth, and through blood transfusions. Syphilis can be transmitted by all components of the blood, making it a comprehensive risk in blood transfusion contexts.

 

While other infections like hepatitis B and C, malaria, and HIV can also be transmitted through blood transfusions, the question specifically asks for an STD. Among the options given, syphilis is the only STD that fits this criterion.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Hepatitis: Incorrect because while hepatitis B and C can be transmitted through blood transfusions, they are not classified primarily as sexually transmitted diseases.

 

Option B. Filariasis: Incorrect because filariasis is a parasitic disease transmitted by mosquitoes, not through blood transfusions or as an STD.

 

Option C. Malaria: Incorrect because malaria is a parasitic infection transmitted by mosquitoes and through blood transfusions, but it is not an STD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Syphilis, caused by Treponema pallidum, is an STD that can be transmitted by all components of the blood, highlighting the importance of thorough blood screening.

questions.text: A 3-month-old child was brought with complaints of umbilical discharge. Abdominal examination was otherwise normal except for the below finding. The next step of management is: (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) USG Abdomen

 

The given image is that of a congenital umbilical anomaly with an apparent discharging sinus. The given clinical scenario is suggestive of embryonal umbilical anomalies such as patent urachus, urachal cyst, and vitelline cyst (resulting from the persistence of omphalomesenteric duct). The next best step in the management of this case is USG abdomen to diagnose if the anomaly is cystic, fibrous, or of fistula.

 

Ultrasonography (USG) of the abdomen is a safe and non-invasive imaging technique commonly used to evaluate abdominal conditions in pediatric patients. It is particularly useful for assessing the umbilical region and identifying any abnormalities that may be causing the umbilical discharge. USG provides real-time imaging and can help in diagnosing conditions such as umbilical granulomas, urachal abnormalities, or other underlying issues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MRI Abdomen: MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging) of the abdomen is a valuable diagnostic tool for various abdominal conditions. However, in the case of a 3-month-old child with umbilical discharge, an ultrasound (USG) is typically the initial imaging modality of choice. MRI is generally reserved for more complex or specific cases.

 

Option C. СЕСТ: CECT may be done after USG if further information was desired.

 

Option D. Exploratory laparotomy: Performing an exploratory laparotomy as the initial step in a 3-month-old child with umbilical discharge and an otherwise normal abdominal examination would be overly aggressive and not indicated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Omphalomesenteric duct abnormalities:

 

  • Vitello intestinal duct or omphalomesenteric duct is the connection between yolk sac and the midgut during embryonic life, which eventually gets obliterated.
  • The persistence of the vitellointestinal duct can lead to various abnormalities according to the part of the duct that is persistent.
  • Persistence of the proximal intestinal end of the duct leads to Meckel's diverticula.
  • Persistence of the distal end near umbilicus leads to umbilical sinus, likely to be the case here.
  • Fully patent vitellointestinal duct can lead to enterocutaneous fistula.

choices.text: Total blood count with peripheral smear

questions.text: A 53-year-old patient was admitted complains of dyspnea. On examination he has puffy face, with engorged veins over the chest. SVC obstruction is suspected. Chest X-ray shows mediastinal enlargement. What is the next step? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CT thorax

 

Superior Vena Cava (SVC) obstruction, suggested by symptoms like dyspnea, facial puffiness, and engorged chest veins, along with a chest X-ray showing mediastinal enlargement, requires further detailed imaging to accurately assess the extent of the obstruction and the presence of any mediastinal masses. A CT scan of the thorax is the most appropriate next step as it provides detailed images of the chest's anatomy, helping to identify the cause of the SVC obstruction, which is crucial for planning appropriate management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Total blood count with peripheral smear: While useful for general health assessments and diagnosing blood disorders, this does not directly address the structural issues seen in SVC obstruction.

 

Option C. Start cyclophosphamide: Beginning chemotherapy like cyclophosphamide would only be appropriate after a specific diagnosis of a malignancy causing the SVC obstruction, confirmed via imaging and biopsy.

 

Option D. Urgent referral to RT: Referral for radiation therapy (RT) may be necessary if a malignancy is confirmed, but it is premature without a detailed thoracic CT and biopsy if indicated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CT thorax is critical for detailed evaluation in suspected SVC obstruction to confirm the diagnosis and guide further specific treatment, whether surgical, medical, or radiation therapy.

questions.text: Imagine being part of a team aiming to identify the link between a novel nutritional supplement and its potential effects on muscle growth. You're tasked with deciding the most appropriate study design to establish a cause-and-effect relationship. Among the given options, which study design would be the most effective for demonstrating a connection between cause and effect? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Cohort study

 

  • Cohort study is the most effective study design for showcasing the connection between a cause and an effect. A cohort study is a type of analytical (observational) study used for ‘hypothesis testing’. It is known by several synonyms:
    • Prospective study
    • Forward looking study
    • Cause to effect study
    • Exposure to outcome study
    • Risk factor to disease study
    • Incidence study
    • Follow up study

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Case-control study: Case Control Study cannot provide with incidences, so Relative Risk cannot be calculated; In a Case Control Study, we calculate ‘an estimate of Relative Risk’, known as ‘Odds Ratio’ (CROSS PRODUCT RATIO).

 

Option C. Cross sectional study: A cross-sectional study is based on the single examination of a cross-section of a population ‘at one point of time’, results of sample are then projected to whole population. It cannot establish causality as ‘does not establish time sequence’.

 

Option D. Clinical trials: Clinical trials evaluates new studies, drugs and treatment effects on human population.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cohort studies are ideal for establishing cause-and-effect relationships by following exposures over time and observing outcomes.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the quadruple screening test? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inhibin B

 

The triple and Quadruple test are done between 15 – 21 weeks.

 

  • Components of Triple test are: Free β hCG, unconjugated Estriol (uE3) and Maternal Serum α-fetoprotein.
  • Components of the Quadruple test are: Free β hCG, unconjugated Estriol (uE3), Maternal Serum α-fetoprotein. And Inhibin A.

 

 

*Easy to remember: B for Big; so in Down’s syndrome; Beta hCG and InhiBin A: Big/ Increased

 

Educational Objective:

 

The quadruple screening test includes Free β hCG, unconjugated Estriol (uE3), Maternal Serum α-fetoprotein (AFP), and Inhibin A. Inhibin B is not included in the quadruple test.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Increase in IL-2, IL-4 and IL-5

questions.text: Mechanism of thalidomide teratogenicity include all except
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Increase in IL-2, IL-4 and IL-5

 

Thalidomide actually suppresses the production of certain cytokines, including IL-2, IL-4, and IL-5. The suppression of these interleukins is part of its immunomodulatory effects, not a mechanism of teratogenicity. Thalidomide suppresses the production of interleukins which is an important mechanism in treatment of multiple myeloma.

 

The exact mechanism of thalidomide's teratogenicity is not completely understood, but several mechanisms have been proposed:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inhibition of angiogenesis: Thalidomide has been found to inhibit angiogenesis, which is the formation of new blood vessels. This inhibition can disrupt the development of the fetus, leading to birth defects. This mechanism is widely accepted as a significant contributor to the teratogenic effects of thalidomide.

 

Option C. Generation of oxygen free radicals: Thalidomide may cause oxidative stress by generating oxygen free radicals, which can damage developing cells. This oxidative stress can contribute to teratogenic effects.

 

Option D. Binding to cereblon: Recent studies have shown that thalidomide binds to a protein called cereblon, which is involved in limb outgrowth and ear development. When thalidomide binds to cereblon, it disrupts the normal function of this protein, leading to the birth defects associated with thalidomide use.

 

Other mechanism includes -

 

  • Interference with cellular signalling: Thalidomide may interfere with various cellular signalling pathways, such as those involving fibroblast growth factors, which are important for embryonic development.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thalidomide's teratogenicity is primarily associated with mechanisms such as the inhibition of angiogenesis, generation of oxygen free radicals, and binding to the cereblon protein. It does not cause an increase in IL-2, IL-4, and IL-5; in fact, it suppresses these interleukins.

questions.text:
Chemoprophylaxis for leprosy should be given to which of the following persons?(INICET NOVEMBER 2022)

 

  1. Sharing the same clothes, towels
  2. Living with a patient with leprosy for > 6 month
  3. Contact of age more than 2 years
  4. Contact for more than 20 hours per week.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2, 3, 4

 

Chemoprophylaxis for leprosy should be given to contacts 2, 3 and 4.

 

Chemoprophylaxis for leprosy should be given to the following contacts:

 

  • Being identified as a contact, i.e., a person who has been in close contact with the index case for 20 hours (option 4) or more per week for more than 3 months (option 2) (Exception is blanket approach where no link with an index case needs to be established.)
  • Age: More than 2 years (option 3); if younger than 2 years, the child can be given SDR at the age of 2, in follow up visits of contacts (if meeting all other inclusion criteria.)
  • Consent of the contact obtained. Depending on the country situation, this can be written or a verbal consent. In case of children, consent should be obtained from the parent or guardian, and sometimes an assent from the grown-up children.
  • Sharing the same clothes and towels (Option 1), while a potential route of transmission, is not generally considered a primary criterion for chemoprophylaxis.

 

Exclusion criteria

 

  • Persons with possible signs and/or symptoms of leprosy;
  • Persons with possible signs and/or symptoms of TB or confirmed with TB;
  • Persons with a history of liver or kidney disorders;
  • Pregnancy; SDR can be given after the delivery;
  • Persons who have received rifampicin in the last two years e.g. as treatment of TB, leprosy or as prophylaxis (e.g. contact of another index case);
  • Persons with history of allergy to rifampicin;
  • Refusal to take SDR.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chemoprophylaxis for leprosy is crucial for contacts who have had significant exposure to an individual with leprosy, particularly those living in the same household or in close contact for extended periods.

 

Rifampicin:

 

  • A single dose of 600 mg kills more than 99% of the susceptible organisms present at the start of treatment, that is as much as 3 to 6 months of daily treatment with the combination dapsone plus Clofazimine.
  • Rifampicin has become established as a highly potent bactericidal drug, and it acts by inhibiting the bacterial DNA dependent RNA polymerase.
  • Single Dose of Rifampicin (SDR) is used in chemoprophylaxis.
  • Chemoprophylaxis must be initiated only 4 weeks after treatment for leprosy has begun in the patient so as to ensure the patient is non-infectious.

 

 

Ref - Jopling’s Handbook of Leprosy 6th Edition Page no 242

Leprosy/Hansen disease: Contact tracing and post-exposure prophylaxis

https://www.who.int/publications/i/item/9789290228073 (page 23, 24)

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3051288/

choices.text: Light green SF
Orange G
Eosin B

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Papanicolaou stain? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Eosin B

 

Eosin B is not a component of Papanicolaou stain.

 

Papanicolaou stain is the most popular stain used in the practice of histopathology. It is a polychrome stain containing multiple dyes to stain the various components of cells differentially. Papanicolaou stain includes both acidic and basic dyes:

 

The classic form of Pap stain involves five dyes in three solutions:

 

  1. A nuclear stain, hematoxylin, is used to stain cell nuclei.
  2. First OG-6 counterstain. The Orange G is used to stain keratin.
  3. Second EA (Eosin Azure) counterstain, comprising of three dyes
    • Eosin Y stains the superficial epithelial squamous cells, nucleoli, cilia, and red blood cells.
    • Light Green SF yellowish stains the cytoplasm of all other cells.
    • Bismarck brown Y – omitted in contemporary formulations

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Light green SF: This dye is used in the Pap stain to color the cytoplasm of various cells green.

 

Option B. Orange G: This dye stains keratin and protein-rich components orange.

 

Option D. Hematoxylin: A nuclear stain used to color cell nuclei blue-purple.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eosin B is not a component of the Papanicolaou stain, which uses a combination of hematoxylin, Orange G, and Eosin Azure (including Eosin Y and Light Green SF) to differentially stain cellular components.

choices.text: Stop MDT and start oral steroids
Continue MDT and add oral steroids

questions.text: In a pregnant woman at 12 weeks of gestation, who is currently undergoing multidrug therapy (MDT) for leprosy, she now presents with type 2 lepra reaction. What is the preferred treatment for this patient?  (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Continue MDT and add oral steroids

 

To manage a pregnant woman experiencing a type 2 lepra reaction, it is essential to continue the multidrug therapy (MDT) while adding oral steroids as an additional treatment.

 

  • In the management of leprosy, it is crucial to continue multidrug therapy (MDT) to effectively treat the underlying infection caused by Mycobacterium leprae.
  • A Type 2 lepra reaction, also known as erythema nodosum leprosum (ENL), is a complex immunological reaction that occurs in lepromatous and borderline lepromatous leprosy, which can present with painful nodules, fever, malaise, and other systemic symptoms.
  • Oral steroids, such as prednisone, are the treatment of choice for controlling acute inflammatory complications associated with Type 2 lepra reaction. They help reduce inflammation and immune response.
  • It is important to manage the reaction without discontinuing the MDT to prevent the development of drug resistance and further progression of the disease.

 

Erythema nodosum leprosum (ENL)

 

  • It is a type 3 hypersensitive immune complex-mediated reaction that affects the skin, nerves, and other organs.
  • It is typically recurrent and commonly observed in individuals with multibacillary leprosy. ENL may occur before treatment, during treatment or after completion of treatment.
  • It is characterized by painful, erythematous nodules appearing on the extensor surfaces of the limbs and face.

 

In a type 2 lepra reaction, systemic symptoms such as iritis, orchitis, and the appearance of fresh skin lesions can be observed.

 

Treatment includes:

 

  • High doses of glucocorticoids are frequently administered to all patients which assist in reducing the acute signs and symptoms of inflammation.
  • In patients with lepra reactions, MDT is never discontinued.
  • Only severe cases of type-2 lepra reaction or erythema nodosum Leprosum are treated with thalidomide. Thalidomide is gold standard for type II Lepra reaction, but it is NOT the Drug of Choice due to its cost factor & also its Adverse drug reactions profile.

 

Type I & II lepra reactions (ENL= Erythema Nodosum Leprosum):

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stop MDT and start oral steroids: Stopping MDT is not advisable because it can lead to the proliferation of Mycobacterium leprae and risk the development of drug resistance.

 

Option B. Antibiotics: While antibiotics are a part of MDT to treat the bacterial infection, they alone are not sufficient to address the acute inflammatory symptoms of a Type 2 lepra reaction.

 

Option C. Thalidomide:

 

  • Thalidomide is an effective treatment for Type 2 lepra reactions due to its potent anti-inflammatory properties.
  • However, it is absolutely contraindicated in pregnant women due to its teratogenic effects, which can cause severe birth defects as seen in the below image.

 

 

Phocomelia

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a pregnant woman with leprosy who presents with a Type 2 lepra reaction, the preferred treatment is to continue multidrug therapy and add oral steroids to manage the acute inflammatory symptoms.
  • Thalidomide is contraindicated in pregnancy due to its teratogenicity.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition Chapter 28 Page no 28.16

Harrison’s principles of internal medicine 21st edition page no 1387, 1390

questions.text:
A patient was brought following an RTA. He was found to have an incomplete lesion of the spinal cord. What would be seen if the central part of the cord was involved? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. LMN lesion of upper limbs and trunk and UMN of lower limbs.
  2. UMN lesion of upper limbs and trunk and LMN of lower limbs.
  3. Bladder and bowel involvement.
  4. Posterior tract involvement.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1 and 3

 

In this patient with central cord syndrome, LMN lesion of upper limbs and trunk, UMN of lower limbs, and bladder and bowel involvement will be seen.

 

Central cord syndrome results from damage to the central region of the spinal cord, specifically affecting the gray matter nerve cells and the decussating spinothalamic tracts surrounding the central canal, which carry crude touch, pain, and temperature sensations.

 

This syndrome commonly occurs due to hyperextension of the cervical spine, causing compression of the spinal cord. Other causes include spinal trauma, syringomyelia, or intrinsic cord tumors.

 

Key clinical features include:

 

  • Arm weakness > leg weakness (upper limb motor loss is more severe than lower limb motor loss).
  • Dissociated sensory loss, with loss of crude touch, pain, and temperature sense, while proprioception and vibration senses are spared.
  • Bilateral lower motor neuron paralysis in the upper limbs and trunk (due to central damage), with upper motor neuron symptoms in the lower limbs.
  • Bladder and bowel dysfunction are frequently involved, and Horner’s syndrome can also occur.

 

This condition typically spares the posterior column, which is responsible for proprioception and fine touch.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1 and 4: While the LMN lesion of the upper limbs is correct, posterior tract involvement is incorrect, as the posterior columns (proprioception and vibration) are usually spared in central cord syndrome.

 

Option B. 2 and 3: UMN lesions of the upper limbs and trunk do not occur in central cord syndrome. Central cord syndrome primarily results in LMN lesions in the upper limbs, with UMN signs in the lower limbs.

 

Option C. 2 and 4: This combination incorrectly suggests UMN lesions in the upper limbs and posterior tract involvement, which are not features of central cord syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Central cord syndrome is characterized by upper limb motor weakness (LMN), lower limb UMN signs, and bladder and bowel dysfunction. It often occurs following hyperextension injuries of the cervical spine and is marked by sensory dissociation (loss of pain and temperature, with sparing of proprioception and fine touch).

questions.text: Which of the following is the most potent stimulator of naive T-cells? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mature dendritic cells

 

Mature dendritic cells are the most potent stimulator of naive T cells as they possess higher levels of MHC-II. They also have costimulatory membrane proteins which are required for activation of T cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Follicular dendritic cells are functionally different from dendritic cells. They are not antigen-presenting-cells and do not activate naive T cells.

 

 

Option C. B lymphocytes: While B cells can act as antigen-presenting cells, they are not as effective as dendritic cells in stimulating naive T cells. They typically present antigens to already activated T cells rather than naive ones.

 

Option D. NK cell: Natural killer (NK) cells are involved in the innate immune response and do not function as antigen-presenting cells. They are responsible for recognizing and killing virally infected cells and tumor cells without the need for antigen presentation.

 

Educational Objective:


Mature dendritic cells are the most potent stimulators of naive T cells due to their high levels of MHC-II and costimulatory molecules.

questions.text: Which transporter is required for the transport of iron into the enterocyte? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Divalent metal transporter 1

 

DMT1 (divalent metal transporter 1) is required for the transport of iron into the enterocyte.

 

Luminal nonheme iron is mostly in the Fe [3] + (ferric state and is reduced to Fe [2] + (ferrous) iron by ferrireductases, such as b cytochromes and STEAP3. Fe [2] + iron is then transported across the apical membrane by divalent metal transporter 1 (DMT1).

 

Fe [2] + iron destined for the circulation, is transported from the cytoplasm across the basolateral enterocyte membrane by ferroportin. This process is coupled to the oxidation of Fe [2] + iron to Fe [3] + iron, which is carried out by the iron oxidases hephaestin and ceruloplasmin.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ferroportin: Ferroportin is not involved in the initial transport of iron into the enterocyte. Instead, it is responsible for exporting iron from the enterocyte into the bloodstream. Ferroportin also works in tandem with hephaestin to ensure that Fe²⁺ iron is oxidized to Fe³⁺ before being released into circulation.

 

Option C. Divalent metal transporter 2: There is no known transporter named "Divalent metal transporter 2" involved in iron absorption or transport within enterocytes. This option is incorrect and may be a distractor or incorrect reference.

 

Option D. Haptocorrin: Haptocorrin is a protein that binds vitamin B12 (cobalamin) in the stomach, protecting it from degradation. It is not involved in iron transport or metabolism, making this option incorrect in the context of iron absorption.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Divalent metal transporter 1 (DMT1) is critical for the transport of Fe²⁺ iron across the apical membrane of enterocytes, facilitating iron absorption in the gut.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotrans pathologic basis of disease 8th edition Pg 1230

questions.text: A patient presents with neck swelling and difficulty in swallowing food. Histopathological examination of the swelling shows increased nests of cells with amyloid deposition. Which of the following is the cell of origin of this mass?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Parafollicular cells

 

Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) is the type of thyroid cancer associated with increased nests of cells and amyloid deposition. MTC arises from the parafollicular cells (also known as C cells) of the thyroid. These cells produce calcitonin, a hormone involved in calcium homeostasis. The presence of amyloid in MTC is due to the deposition of calcitonin, which can be detected as amyloid material in histopathological examinations. This type of thyroid cancer is distinct from other forms such as papillary, follicular, or anaplastic thyroid carcinomas, which originate from follicular cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endothelial cells: Incorrect. Endothelial cells line blood vessels and are not associated with thyroid tumors that show amyloid deposition.

 

Option C. Follicular cells: Incorrect. Follicular cells give rise to papillary, follicular, and anaplastic thyroid cancers, not medullary thyroid carcinoma.

 

Option D. Hurthle cells: Incorrect. Hurthle cells are a variant of follicular cells and can be seen in Hurthle cell carcinoma, another type of thyroid cancer, but not in medullary thyroid carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Medullary thyroid carcinoma, characterized by nests of cells and amyloid deposition, arises from the parafollicular cells (C cells) of the thyroid.

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿Entry of calcium into sarcoplasmic reticulum

questions.text: Myosin head detaches from actin by which of the following mechanism? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Binding of ATP

 

Binding of ATP on the free site of myosin leads to the detachment of myosin head from the thin filament.

 

 

Energy for movement of myosin head (power stroke) is obtained by breakdown of adenosine triphosphate (ATP) into adenosine diphosphate (ADP) and inorganic phosphate (Pi). Head of myosin has a site for ATP and itself can act as the enzyme ATPase and catalyse the breakdown of ATP.

 

Even before the onset of contraction, an ATP molecule binds with myosin head.

When tropomyosin moves to expose the active sites, the head is attached to the active site. Now ATPase cleaves ATP into ADP and Pi, which remains in head itself. The energy released during this process is utilized for contraction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Entry of calcium into sarcoplasmic reticulum: Incorrect. The entry of calcium into the sarcoplasmic reticulum helps in muscle relaxation but does not directly cause the detachment of the myosin head from actin.

 

Option C. Change in troponin C configuration: Incorrect. The change in troponin C configuration exposes the active sites on actin for myosin binding but does not cause detachment.

 

Option D. Release of ADP and Pi: Incorrect. The release of ADP and Pi occurs after the power stroke but does not cause the detachment of the myosin head.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The detachment of the myosin head from actin is caused by the binding of ATP to the myosin head, which is a critical step in the muscle contraction and relaxation cycle.

questions.text: Identify the lesion in the histopathological image of retina: (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Drusen  

 

  • Drusen, also called colloid bodies, are extracellular deposits located at the interface between the Retinal Pigmentary Epithelium and Bruch membrane.
  • Drusen are numerous, minute, whitish, refractile spots with pigmented margins, mainly involving the posterior pole.
  • They are seen in senile macular degeneration and Doyne's honeycomb dystrophy.
  • The material of which they are composed has a broad range of constituents and is thought to be derived from immune-mediated and metabolic processes in the retinal pigmentary epithelium.
  • The precise role of drusen in the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration (AMD) is unclear.
  • However, drusen are positively associated with the size of lesions and the presence or absence of associated pigmentary abnormalities.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hard exudates: Well-defined, bright yellow deposits of extravasated fluid rich in fibrin and proteins. These hyaline or lipid deposits are generally seen as a cluster around a group of leaking microaneurysms. Commonly seen in macular area, in the outer plexiform layer.

 

Option C. Cotton-wool spots: Composed of accumulations of neuronal debris within the nerve fibre layer.

 

Option D. Macular edema: Accumulation of excess fluid in the extracellular space within the retina in the macular area.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Drusen are distinct, granular deposits at the interface between the retinal pigment epithelium and Bruch's membrane, commonly associated with age-related macular degeneration and can be an early sign of the disease.

questions.text: While working at a rural health sub-centre, you and a medical intern are analyzing annual infant registration metrics. The intern inquires about the expected annual infant registration rate when a health worker is actively on duty at the sub center. What is the best representation of this rate? [AIIMS MAY 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 150

 

Each year, a total of 150 infants should be enrolled at a sub-centre.

 

Annual infant population = Total population × % infants in population or expected birth rate

 

The infant population percentage, or the anticipated birth rate, ought to be derived from local data. In cases where a specific local percentage is not accessible, it is approximated at 3% of the overall population.

 

Total population in a sub centre = 5000.

 

Here, annual infant population = 5000 × 3/100 = 150

 

Total population catered by a Sub centre = 5000

 

Crude birth rate (CBR) India = 19 per 1000 Mid-year population (SRS 2016)

 

So, estimated number of births in a year = 19/1000 ×5000 = 95 births per year

 

  • Also, current Infant mortality rate (IMR) India = 28 per 1000 Live births
  • So, Expected number of infant deaths in a year in that population = 28/1000 × 95 = 2.7 deaths
  • So, total number of expected alive infants = 95 – 2.7 = 92 Infants approximately

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a rural health sub-centre, the expected annual infant registration rate effectively captures both the births and adjustments for infant mortality.
  • The number 150 serves as a practical target for ensuring all newborns are accounted for within the community health system.
  • This figure supports proactive health planning and resource allocation, emphasizing the importance of accurate and timely health data registration.

questions.text: The microorganism demonstrates resistance to meropenem and aminoglycosides, while being susceptible to ticarcillin-clavulanate and cotrimoxazole. Which microorganism is most likely responsible? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stenotrophomonas maltophila

 

  • Stenotrophomonas maltophila, previously known as Pseudomonas maltophila, is an opportunistic pathogen responsible for wound infections, urinary tract infections, and septicemia.
  • It displays susceptibility to cotrimoxazole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Proteus mirabilis:

 

  • Resistant to: Nitrofurantoin, Tetracyclines
  • Susceptible to aminoglycosides, carbapenems, cephalosporins, cotromoxazole, penicillin+ β-lactamase inhibitors.
  • Clinical manifestations: Respiratory infections, especially in cystic fibrosis patients, and opportunistic infections.

 

Option C. Pseudomonas aeruginosa:

 

  • Known for resistance to multiple antibiotics, but typically not specifically resistant to meropenem.
  • Susceptible to: A wide range of antibiotics, often including aminoglycosides, depending on the strain.
  • Clinical manifestations: Respiratory infections, wound infections, and urinary tract infections.

 

Option D. Acinetobacter baumannii:

 

  • Known for multi-drug resistance, including to carbapenems like meropenem.
  • Susceptibility varies, but generally not as consistently susceptible to ticarcillin-clavulanate as Stenotrophomonas maltophila.
  • Clinical manifestations: Hospital-acquired infections, such as pneumonia and bloodstream infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stenotrophomonas maltophila is an opportunistic pathogen resistant to meropenem and aminoglycosides but susceptible to ticarcillin-clavulanate and cotrimoxazole.

choices.text: Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS)

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient has proteinuria. Looking at the immunofluorescence image below, what is the diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lupus nephritis

 

The given immunofluorescence staining of the kidney biopsy specimen shows positive staining for fibrinogen, IgG, IgA, IgM, C1q, C3, λ chain, and k light chain. This is known as full-house effect. It is seen in lupus nephritis.

 

Six patterns of lupus nephritis

 

  1. Class I - Minimal lesions - deposits within the mesangium positive for IgG and C3.
  2. Class II – Mesangial lupus nephritis - Granular mesangial deposits of IgG and C3; sometimes IgA and IgM are also present in the deposits.
  3. Class III – Focal segmental lupus nephritis - Subendothelial and subepithelial deposits of IgG, often with IgM or IgA and C3, are seen.
  4. Class IV – Diffuse lupus nephritis – Most severe and most common. Deposits in the mesangium and in the subendothelial region which on immunofluorescence are positive for IgG; sometimes also for IgA or IgM, and C3.
  5. Class V – Membranous Lupus Nephritis - subendothelial deposits of immune complexes containing IgG, IgM and C3
  6. Class VI – Sclerosing Lupus nephritis - End-stage kidney of SLE. Most glomeruli are sclerosed and hyalinised and there may be remnants of preceding lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS): This does not typically show a full-house pattern on immunofluorescence. FSGS is usually characterized by segmental glomerular scarring and may show focal deposits of IgM and C3.

 

Option B. Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSG): This condition typically shows deposits of IgG and C3 in a "starry sky" pattern on immunofluorescence but does not display a full-house pattern.

 

Option C. Goodpasture syndrome: This typically shows linear deposits of IgG along the glomerular basement membrane, without the full-house pattern seen in lupus nephritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The full-house effect on immunofluorescence (positive staining for IgG, IgA, IgM, C1q, C3, λ chain, and κ light chain) is a hallmark of lupus nephritis.

 

Ref: Robbins Pathologic basis of disease 8th edition, Pg 409-410

choices.text: Repeat Inj. adenosine 6 mg
Inj. amiodarone 300 mg

questions.text: The ECG of a patient who presented to the ER is as given below. The patient was already given a carotid massage and IV Adenosine but the BP is currently 60/30 mm Hg. What is the next best step of management? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Synchronized Cardioversion

 

Any hemodynamically unstable rhythm, requires synchronized cardioversion (Shock delivered in sync with R wave to prevent R-on T phenomenon).

 

Synchronized Cardioversion is the correct choice for a hemodynamically unstable patient, as it is intended to restore normal heart rhythm without causing further cardiac risks. Synchronization ensures that the shock is delivered at a safe point in the QRS complex to prevent the induction of ventricular fibrillation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Maximum of 30mg of adenosine can be tried if patient is Hemodynamically Stable

 

Option C. Amiodarone is used in the treatment of chronic arrhythmias and rarely for acute treatment of SVT

 

Option D. DC cardioversion technically refers to the same treatment as synchronized cardioversion in the context of unstable rhythms but the lack of specification about synchronization could imply a risk if not properly timed.

 

Synchronised cardioversion avoid possibility of R on T phenomenon.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of hemodynamically unstable tachyarrhythmias where initial pharmacological interventions fail, synchronized cardioversion should be promptly employed to stabilize the patient. This technique is crucial for preventing progression to more severe complications such as cardiac arrest.

questions.text: All of the following are growth promoting proto-oncogenes except? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) TGF beta

 

TGF beta (Transforming Growth Factor beta) is the exception in this list as it is not a growth-promoting proto-oncogene. Instead, TGF beta is a classic example of a tumor suppressor protein. The TGF-beta/SMAD complex acts as a tumor suppressor complex, inhibiting cell growth and promoting apoptosis in normal cells. Loss of function mutations in the TGF-beta pathway can contribute to cancer development by removing this growth-inhibitory signal.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. FGF (Fibroblast Growth Factor): FGF is indeed a growth-promoting proto-oncogene. It stimulates cell proliferation and survival in various cell types.

 

Option B. PDGF (Platelet-Derived Growth Factor): PDGF is a growth-promoting proto-oncogene. It plays a crucial role in cell growth, division, and blood vessel formation.

 

Option C. TGF alpha (Transforming Growth Factor alpha): TGF alpha is a growth-promoting proto-oncogene. It stimulates cell proliferation and is often overexpressed in various cancers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Among growth factors, TGF beta stands out as a tumor suppressor, while FGF, PDGF, and TGF alpha are growth-promoting proto-oncogenes. Understanding the distinct roles of these factors is crucial in comprehending cancer biology and developing targeted therapies.

questions.text: Which of the following finger has two dorsal interossei muscles? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Middle finger

 

Explanation:

 

The middle finger has two dorsal interossei muscles flanking it. One is positioned between the index and middle fingers, and the other is positioned between the middle and ring fingers.

 

This anatomical configuration allows the middle finger to be abducted in both directions: towards the index finger and towards the ring finger.

 

 

The dorsal interossei muscles are four bipennate muscles located between the metacarpal bones in the hand. They are named "dorsal" because they are located on the dorsum (back) of the hand, and "interossei" means between bones. Their main action is to abduct the fingers away from the axial line, which runs down the center of the third (middle) finger.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Index finger: This finger has one dorsal interosseous muscle which abducts the index finger away from the middle finger.

 

Option B. Little finger: The little finger also has one dorsal interosseous muscle. This muscle abducts the little finger away from the ring finger.

 

Option D. Ring finger: The ring finger has one dorsal interosseous muscle which abducts it away from the little finger.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient is diagnosed with acute myeloid leukemia. The peripheral blood smear picture is given in the image. The cell indicated by the arrow is best described as: (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Faggot cell

 

The picture shows multiple Auer rods clustered in a single cell resembling a bundle of sticks.

 

Such cells are called faggot cells (faggot meaning bundle of sticks in French). Faggot cells are characteristic of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), a subtype of acute myeloid leukemia (AML) associated with the t(15;17) translocation.

 

The presence of faggot cells is particularly indicative of APL, where the leukemic promyelocytes have an abundance of Auer rods. Auer rods are distinctive needle-like azurophilic granules formed by the fusion of primary (azurophilic) granules. While Auer rods can be seen in other subtypes of AML, the clustering of these rods within a single cell to form a faggot cell is most commonly associated with APL.

 

Since the question is particularly about the cell, the best answer from the given options is faggot cell and not Auer rods.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Auer rods: Auer rods are distinctive needle-like azurophilic granules present in many cases but particularly numerous in AML with the t(15;17) aberration (acute promyelocytic leukemia).

 

Option B. Flaming promyelocyte: Flaming promyelocyte is an abnormal promyelocyte with disintegrating cytoplasm and liberating Auer rods and granules into the surrounding marrow. Found in APL

 

Option C. Dusky promyelocyte: Promyelocytes with fine granules appearing dusky or hazy are called dusky promyelocytes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A faggot cell, characterized by multiple Auer rods clustered together in a single cell, is highly indicative of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL). While Auer rods are a feature of various forms of AML, the presence of faggot cells is particularly associated with APL.

 

Ref: Robbin and Cotrans pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Pg 1154

questions.text: FISH can detect all except which of the following? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Point mutation

 

Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) is a cytogenetic technique used to detect and localize specific DNA sequences on chromosomes. It can detect chromosomal abnormalities such as amplifications, deletions, and translocations. However, FISH cannot detect point mutations because these are small-scale changes in DNA sequence that occur at the molecular level, not at the chromosomal level that FISH is designed to analyze.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Amplification: As FISH can detect gene amplifications, which are increases in the number of copies of a particular gene.

 

Option B. Deletion: Because FISH can identify chromosomal deletions, where a segment of a chromosome is missing.

 

Option C. Translocation: As FISH is commonly used to detect chromosomal translocations, where segments of chromosomes have exchanged places.

 

Educational Objective:

 

FISH (Fluorescence in situ hybridization) can detect chromosomal abnormalities like amplifications, deletions, and translocations, but cannot detect point mutations, which require molecular methods such as PCR for identification.

choices.text: Labile hypertension
Pulmonary hypertension
Treatment of resistant migraine
Resistant Parkinson's disease

questions.text: Inhaled Nitric oxide is approved for treatment of? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pulmonary hypertension

 

Inhaled Nitric Oxide (NO) has specific clinical applications, particularly in the field of pulmonary medicine. It is approved for the treatment of pulmonary hypertension, especially in certain acute settings. It works by selectively dilating the pulmonary vessels by increasing cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP), thereby reducing pulmonary artery pressure and improving oxygenation. Inhaled nitric oxide is particularly noted for its use in newborns with hypoxic respiratory failure associated with pulmonary hypertension. It can also be used in the acute management of pulmonary hypertension in adults during cardiac surgery or critical care settings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Labile Hypertension: Inhaled nitric oxide is not used for the treatment of labile hypertension. Hypertension is typically managed with systemic medications rather than inhaled agents.

 

Option C. Treatment of Resistant Migraine: Inhaled nitric oxide is not a standard treatment for migraines, whether typical or resistant. Migraine treatment usually involves a range of other pharmacological interventions.

 

Option D. Resistant Parkinson's Disease: There is no established role for inhaled nitric oxide in the treatment of Parkinson’s disease. Parkinson's disease management primarily involves medications that affect dopamine pathways.

 

Other uses of inhaled Nitric Oxide:

 

  • Neonatal Care: It is particularly valuable in the treatment of newborns with persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn (PPHN) to improve oxygenation.
  • Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS): While its benefits in ARDS in adults are still a subject of research and debate, it has been used for its pulmonary vasodilator effects in some critical care settings.
  • Cardiac Surgery: Inhaled NO can be used during cardiac surgery to control pulmonary artery pressures.
  • Lung Transplantation: It may be used to reduce pulmonary hypertension and improve graft function immediately after transplantation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inhaled Nitric Oxide is approved for the treatment of pulmonary hypertension, particularly in acute settings to reduce pulmonary artery pressure and improve oxygenation. It is not used for labile hypertension, migraines, or Parkinson's disease.

choices.text: Abdominal pain or discomfort is the commonest presentation for ectopic in 90%
Oral methotrexate is the choice of medical management in patient with shock
Ectopic pregnancy is increased in patient with history of PID
Patient will have reduced levels of progesterone but is not diagnostic

questions.text: A 26-year woman with six weeks of amenorrhea presents with sharp lower abdominal pain, light vaginal spotting and a bp of 90/ 60 mmHg.  pelvic exam reveals right adnexal tenderness. Choose the incorrect statement about this condition. (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Oral methotrexate is the choice of medical management in patient with shock

 

The clinical scenario describes a classic presentation of ruptured ectopic pregnancy with the triad of amenorrhea, pain, and vaginal bleeding, along with signs of shock (BP 90/60 mmHg) and adnexal tenderness. The statement about oral methotrexate is incorrect because:

 

  1. Methotrexate is given as an intramuscular injection, not orally
  2. Medical management is contraindicated in patients with shock; they require immediate surgical intervention
  3. Hemodynamic instability is an absolute contraindication to medical management

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Abdominal pain or discomfort is the commonest presentation for ectopic in 90%: Pain is indeed the most common presenting symptom of ectopic pregnancy, occurring in approximately 90% of cases. The clinical triad includes pain, amenorrhea, and vaginal bleeding.

 

Option C. Ectopic pregnancy is increased in patient with history of PID: PID increases the risk of ectopic pregnancy by causing salpingitis, which reduces tubal motility and can lead to implantation within the fallopian tube.

 

Option D. Patient will have reduced levels of progesterone but is not diagnostic: While progesterone levels are typically lower in ectopic pregnancy compared to normal intrauterine pregnancy, this finding is not diagnostic and is not used for clinical decision-making.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Medical management with methotrexate is contraindicated in ectopic pregnancy with hemodynamic instability (shock); such cases require immediate surgical intervention.

questions.text:
Arrange the sequence of steps in leukocyte migration: 

 

a. Stable adhesion
b. Integration activation by chemokine
c. Rolling
d. Migration through endothelium
questions.solution:
Ans. A) c, b, a, d

 

Leukocyte migration from the bloodstream to the tissue during inflammation is a multi-step process:

 

  1. Rolling (c): Leukocytes first "roll" along the endothelium. This process is mediated by selectins, which interact with glycoproteins on the leukocyte surface. Rolling allows leukocytes to slow down and move along the vessel wall.
  2. Activation by chemokines (b): Chemokines activate integrins on leukocytes, increasing their affinity for adhesion molecules on the endothelial surface.
  3. Stable adhesion (a): Once integrins are activated, leukocytes firmly adhere to the endothelium through integrin-mediated binding.

 

Migration through endothelium (d): Finally, leukocytes migrate across the endothelial barrier into the tissue through a process called diapedesis, following a chemotactic gradient to the site of inflammation.

 

 

Educational Objective:


Leukocyte migration involves rolling, chemokine-mediated integrin activation, stable adhesion, and migration across the endothelium, a crucial sequence in the immune response during inflammation.

questions.text:
In haemolytic anaemia, which of the following is correct? (INICET NOV 2024)

 

  1. Urobilinogen is high
  2. Serum conjugated bilirubin is elevated
  3. Serum transaminases are increased
  4. Indirect van den Bergh reaction is positive
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 4

 

In haemolytic anaemia, there is increased destruction of red blood cells leading to elevated unconjugated (indirect) bilirubin. This results in:

 

1. Urobilinogen is high: Increased urobilinogen in urine due to normal enterohepatic circulation

 

4. Indirect van den Bergh reaction is positive: Positive indirect van den Bergh reaction due to elevated unconjugated bilirubin

 

These findings are characteristic of haemolytic anaemia and help differentiate it from other causes of jaundice.

 

Other Options:

 

2. Serum conjugated bilirubin is elevated: Incorrect, as conjugated bilirubin elevation is typically seen in obstructive jaundice or hepatic diseases, not in haemolytic anaemia

 

3. Serum transaminases are increased: Incorrect, as elevated transaminases indicate liver cell damage, which is not a feature of haemolytic anaemia

 

Educational Objective:

 

Haemolytic anaemia is characterized by:

 

  • Increased urobilinogen in urine
  • Elevated unconjugated (indirect) bilirubin
  • Positive indirect van den Bergh reaction
  • Normal enterohepatic circulation

questions.text: Which of the following, all are findings of the condition in the below chest X-ray except: (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pulmonary venous hypertension

 

The chest X-ray provided shows the characteristic "egg-on-a-string" appearance, which is indicative of Transposition of the Great Arteries (TGA). In TGA, the aorta arises from the right ventricle and the pulmonary artery arises from the left ventricle, leading to parallel circulation. This is a severe congenital heart defect that requires immediate attention.

 

In TGA, the following findings are seen:

 

  • Right atrial enlargement: This occurs due to increased venous return to the right side of the heart, as blood from the body is directed to the right atrium and ventricle, which then pumps it to the aorta and systemic circulation. This enlargement is visible on the X-ray.
  • Narrow vascular pedicle: The "string" appearance of the mediastinum is due to a narrow vascular pedicle, which is a common radiographic finding in TGA. This narrowness results from the abnormal positioning and arrangement of the great arteries.
  • Increased pulmonary blood flow: Depending on the presence and size of any associated shunts (like a patent ductus arteriosus or a ventricular septal defect), there can be increased pulmonary blood flow, which is often observed in cases of TGA.

 

However, pulmonary venous hypertension is not a typical finding in TGA. Pulmonary venous hypertension is usually seen in conditions that increase pressure in the pulmonary veins, such as left heart failure or mitral valve disease. It is not characteristic of TGA, where the primary issue is with the arteries and not the pulmonary veins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased pulmonary blood flow: This can occur in TGA, especially if there is a shunt allowing some oxygenated blood to reach the systemic circulation.

 

Option B. Narrow vascular pedicle: The "string" part of the "egg-on-a-string" appearance refers to the narrow mediastinum, which is due to the narrow vascular pedicle, a common finding in TGA.

 

Option C. Right atrial enlargement: Right atrial enlargement: Enlargement of the right atrium is seen in TGA due to the abnormal circulation pattern but is a rare feature.
Both atria can enlarge in TGA, but left predominates
With mixing lesions (VSD, ASD), right atrial enlargement can happen

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "egg-on-a-string" appearance on a chest X-ray is characteristic of Transposition of the Great Arteries (TGA), and pulmonary venous hypertension is not a typical finding in this condition.

choices.text: Vigorous term babies not requiring resuscitation
All preterm babies irrespective of birth weight
Vigorous term and preterm babies not requiring resuscitation
All term babies irrespective of birth weight

questions.text: When is delayed cord clamping done? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vigorous term and preterm babies not requiring resuscitation

 

According to WHO guidelines, delayed cord clamping should be performed in all vigorous term and preterm babies who do not require resuscitation. This practice has been incorporated into the active management of third stage of labor (AMTSL) protocol. The primary benefit is the prevention of neonatal anemia, with particular effectiveness in preterm infants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vigorous term babies not requiring resuscitation: Incorrect because it excludes preterm babies, who benefit more from delayed cord clamping

 

Option B. All preterm babies irrespective of birth weight: Incorrect because it includes preterm babies requiring resuscitation, which is a contraindication for delayed cord clamping

 

Option D. All term babies irrespective of birth weight: Incorrect because it includes babies requiring resuscitation, which is a contraindication for delayed cord clamping

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Delayed cord clamping should be performed in all vigorous term and preterm babies not requiring resuscitation, with the only contraindication being the need for immediate resuscitation in an asphyxiated baby.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents to the Pediatrics OPD with the complaints of several episodes of melena. On physical examination, there was eczematous rash over the skin with multiple red pin-point hemorrhagic spots. His Hemogram reveals low platelet count and normal RBC and WBC counts. What is the next best investigation? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) WASP gene mutation

 

The clinical symptoms of the patient (recurrent Melena, eczema and red pin-point hemorrhagic spots) are pointing towards the diagnosis of Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome. It occurs due to WASP gene mutation.

 

So Next best step would be to analyze for WASP mutation (Chromosome Xp).

 

Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome is an X-linked recessive immunodeficiency disorder characterized by –

 

  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Recurrent bleeding (Melena, Epistaxis or Hematemesis)
  • Low Immunity, Recurrent Infections, Eczema
  • Low IgM and high IgA & IgE
  • Normal thymus but reduced T-cells in blood

 

The only treatment for this condition is Bone Marrow Transplantation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anti-platelet antibodies: While these are relevant in conditions like immune thrombocytopenia (ITP), they are not the primary investigation for Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome.

 

Option C. Bone marrow biopsy: This can be used to assess marrow function but is not specific for diagnosing Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome.

 

Option D. Electron microscopy: Although useful in some hematological disorders, it is not the first-line diagnostic tool for Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome should be suspected in a pediatric patient with thrombocytopenia, eczema, and recurrent bleeding episodes, and the next best step is to investigate for a WASP gene mutation.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 439-440

choices.text: Bone Marrow biopsy with reticulin stain

questions.text: A young boy from high altitude came with fever and weakness and had the following reports Hemoglobin 17 gm%, TLC is 21,000 with neutrophils 25, lymphocytes 30, eosinophils 5, myelocytes and metamyelocytes 40 in peripheral smear. Next step in the investigation should be: (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Erythropoietin levels

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of polycythemia (Hb>16 g/dL). Erythropoietin levels should be determined to differentiate primary from secondary forms.

 

Polycythemia vera (PCV) is characterized by increased marrow production of red cells, granulocytes, and platelets (panmyelosis), but it is the increase in red cells (polycythemia), that is responsible for most of the clinical symptoms. PCV must be differentiated from relative polycythemia resulting from hemoconcentration and other causes of absolute polycythemia. PCV is strongly associated with activating point mutations in the tyrosine kinase JAK2.

 

In PCV the progenitor cells have markedly decreased requirements for erythropoietin and other hematopoietic growth factors due to constitutive JAK2 signaling. Accordingly, serum erythropoietin levels in PCV are very low, whereas secondary forms of absolute polycythemia have high erythropoietin levels.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Philadelphia chromosome: This test is relevant in diagnosing chronic myeloid leukemia (CML), not polycythemia. While the presence of immature myeloid cells (myelocytes and metamyelocytes) could suggest a myeloproliferative disorder, the patient's clinical presentation and high hemoglobin level are more consistent with polycythemia, making erythropoietin testing a more appropriate next step.

 

Option B. JAK mutation: Testing for the JAK2 mutation is crucial in confirming a diagnosis of PCV. However, before proceeding to this test, it is important to measure erythropoietin levels to differentiate between primary and secondary polycythemia. If erythropoietin levels are low, JAK2 mutation analysis would then be the next step.

 

Option D. Bone Marrow biopsy with reticulin stain: This investigation is used to evaluate bone marrow fibrosis, which can occur in myeloproliferative disorders like PCV. However, it is not the first-line investigation in this scenario. The erythropoietin level is a less invasive test that provides critical information to guide further diagnostic steps.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Erythropoietin levels should be measured to differentiate between primary and secondary polycythemia. In cases of polycythemia vera, erythropoietin levels are typically low due to constitutive JAK2 signaling, while secondary polycythemia is associated with high erythropoietin levels.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cortans pathologic basis of disease, Pg 1161, 1242

choices.text: FEV1 < 0.85 and FEV1/FVC <0.8
FEV1 < 0.85 and FEV1/FVC <0.75
FEV1 < 0.8 and FEV1/FVC <0.7
FEV1 < 0.8 and FEV1/FVC <0.75

questions.text:
A 60-year-old male patient has grade III ASA. Which of the following post bronchodilator PFT findings requires further evaluation of the lung function of the patient? (INICET Nov 2021)

ASA- American Society of Anesthesiology

PFT- Pulmonary function test

FEV1 - Forced expiratory volume in 1 second

FVC- Forced vital capacity
questions.solution:
Ans. C. FEV1 < 0.8 and FEV1/FVC <0.7

 

This option shows a significant reduction in both FEV1 and the FEV1/FVC ratio. An FEV1/FVC ratio of less than 0.7 is a clear indicator of obstructive lung disease. Combined with the reduced FEV1, this suggests significant lung dysfunction that requires further evaluation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. FEV1 < 0.85 and FEV1/FVC <0.8: While these values indicate some reduction in lung function, they do not meet the threshold for a definitive diagnosis of obstructive lung disease. The FEV1/FVC ratio is still above the critical cutoff of 0.7.

 

Option B. FEV1 < 0.85 and FEV1/FVC <0.75: These values suggest reduced lung function but not to the extent that is indicative of moderate or severe COPD. The FEV1/FVC ratio is below 0.8 but not yet at the critical threshold of 0.7.

 

Option D. FEV1 < 0.8 and FEV1/FVC <0.75: While the FEV1 is below 0.8, the FEV1/FVC ratio is not at the critical threshold of 0.7, so it does not indicate significant obstructive lung disease requiring further evaluation.

 

Educational Objective :

 

As per GOLD criteria for COPD, FEV1 <0.8 and FEV1/FVC <0.7 are classified as moderate COPD and require further evaluation of lung function.

 

GOLD criteria for COPD is given as follows:

 

 

Abbreviations: COPD, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease; GOLD, Global Initiative for Lung Disease

 

As per GOLD criteria for COPD, FEV1 <0.8 and FEV1/FVC <0.7 are classified as moderate COPD and require further evaluation of the lung function.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 950

choices.text: Get consent from mother for P/V

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl presents to you with her mother, reporting abdominal discomfort and is found to be 12 weeks pregnant based on a positive urine pregnancy test. As a medical professional, what would be your initial course of action? [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Inform Police

 

Explanation

 

In many jurisdictions, pregnancy in a minor may be considered evidence of statutory rape or sexual abuse, hence, informing the police is crucial for legal proceedings and safeguarding the minor.

 

Other Option

 

Option A. Start examining: Although a medical examination is necessary, it must be conducted with proper legal and parental consent, especially considering the age and the situation's sensitivity.

 

Option C. Preserve clothing: This could be necessary in a case where forensic evidence needs to be gathered, especially if there was recent assault. However, this would follow legal reporting.

 

Option D. Take consent from mother: Consent is crucial, especially for minors. However, it does not preclude the obligation to report statutory rape or sexual abuse to authorities.

 

Educational objective :

 

  • When dealing with potentially criminal situations involving minors, such as a young teenager's pregnancy, the first step is to ensure the situation is addressed legally and safely. 
  • Informing law enforcement and ensuring proper medical and legal procedures safeguard the minor's health and legal rights.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure in the given CT image. (INICET NOVEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pneumatised superior turbinate

 

The superior turbinates form one of the three pairs of conchae in the nose and represent part of the labyrinth of the ethmoid bone, arising as bony projections from its posterior surface.

 

The air passage between the superior nasal concha and the lateral nasal wall is known as the superior meatus and forms part of the nasal cavity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Concha bullosa is a pneumatized middle turbinate.

 

 

Option C. Onodi cell/ Sphenoethmoidal air cell is the posterior most ethmoidal air cell.

 

 

Option D. Haller cell/ infraorbital ethmoidal air cells are ethmoid air cells located lateral to the maxillo-ethmoidal suture along the inferomedial orbital floor.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pneumatisation of the superior turbinate, indicates the presence of air spaces within the turbinates, which can have implications for nasal physiology and potential sinus pathologies.

questions.text: Given below is the demonstration of tetanisation in the gastrocnemius muscle of a frog. Identify the tetanising frequency? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 20-25 Hz

 

Tetanizing frequency demonstrated by the muscle is 25Hz.

 

Tetanizing frequency: Rate of stimulation at which summation of contractions will occur
