Tetanizing frequency can be calculated as à 1/contraction period.

 

As per the graph -

  • ﻿﻿Paper speed - 1000mm/sec.
  • ﻿﻿y-axis represents force of muscle contraction millivolts
  • x-axis represents duration of contraction in milliseconds with a scale of 10mm
  • ﻿﻿The scale on the x-axis is 10mm.
  • ﻿﻿Area under the graph is the muscle contraction.

 

Contraction period the duration from latent period to maximum force of contraction

So, in the given graph,

Contraction period is approximately 4 scales i.e., 40 mm.

As the speed of the paper is 1000mm/sec, contraction period = 40mm = (40/1000) = 40 msec = 0.04sec

Tetanizing frequency = 1/contraction period = 1/0.04 = 100/4 = 25Hz.

 

Educational Objective

 

Tetanisation

 

As the frequency increases, there comes a point where each new contraction occurs before the preceding one is over. As a result, the second contraction is added partially to the first, so that the total strength of contraction rises progressively with increasing frequency. When the frequency reaches a critical level, the successive contractions eventually become so rapid that they fuse together, and the whole muscle contraction appears to be completely smooth and continuous. This is called tetanization.

choices.text: 1-b, 2-c, 3-d, 4-a
1-a, 2-b, 3-d, 4-c
1-d, 2-c, 3-a, 4-b
1-c, 2-b, 3-d, 4-a

questions.text: Match the following scale types with their lesions?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-b, 2-c, 3-d, 4-a

 

Matched Pairs:

 

  • 1-b: Collarette scales - Pityriasis Rosea: Collarette scales are characteristic of Pityriasis Rosea, where these scales are fine, peripherally attached but centrally detached, often found around the edge of the herald patch or subsequent lesions.
  • 2-c: Silvery scales - Psoriasis: Silvery scales are hallmark features of Psoriasis. These scales are typically seen as thick, shiny, and silvery white, indicative of excessive proliferation of skin layers, particularly due to parakeratosis.
  • 3-d: Mica-like scales - Pityriasis lichenoides chronica: Mica-like scales in Pityriasis lichenoides chronica refer to the fine, adherent scales that resemble mineral mica, found on polymorphic lesions that can also show hemorrhagic crusting.
  • 4-a: Branny scales - Pityriasis versicolor: Branny scales are a feature of Pityriasis versicolor, described as fine, powdery, and often easily detachable, much like bran. These scales highlight the superficial fungal infection's impact on the skin.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Educational objective:

 

Diseases & special scales:

 

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition Chapter 28 Page no 4.13, 26.2, 29.15, 40.1-40.5, 50.6, 65.2, 107.3, 109.8

questions.text: Purkinje cells of cerebellum relay into: (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Dentate nucleus

 

Explanation:

 

The cerebellum's purkinje cells relay information to the dentate nucleus, one of the deep cerebellar nuclei.

 

It is the cerebellum's distinguishing cell. It is a large flask-shaped cell. Climbing fibres from the inferior olivary nucleus stimulate it. This cell's main output is inhibitory in nature and is directed at cerebellar nuclei. These are the most important output neurons.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Caudate Nucleus: It's one of the structures that make up the basal ganglia in the brain. The caudate nucleus has a long, C-shaped structure and is located laterally in the brain, near the lateral ventricles. It plays roles in various functions like voluntary movement control, learning, memory, and emotion. Purkinje cells do not primarily relay into the caudate nucleus.

 

Option B. Lentiform Nucleus: Another component of the basal ganglia, the lentiform nucleus is located deep within the brain and is laterally placed in relation to the thalamus. The lentiform nucleus is made up of two structures: the putamen and the globus pallidus. It's involved in movement regulation and other functions. Purkinje cells do not have a direct relay into the lentiform nucleus.

 

Option D. Red Nucleus: Found in the midbrain, the red nucleus has a reddish hue due to its rich blood supply and the presence of iron. It plays a role in motor coordination, particularly in the coordination of limb movements. While the red nucleus does receive input from the cerebellum, the primary relay from Purkinje cells is to the deep cerebellar nuclei, not directly to the red nucleus. The dentate nucleus, in turn, can send projections to the red nucleus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dentate Nucleus is one of the deep cerebellar nuclei and is situated within the white matter of the cerebellum. The dentate nucleus is the largest of the deep cerebellar nuclei and plays a role in the planning, initiation, and control of voluntary movements.

 

Purkinje cells in the cerebellar cortex send inhibitory projections to the deep cerebellar nuclei, including the dentate nucleus. This is the main output pathway for the cerebellar cortex.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman presented in OPD with complaints of fatigue and weakness. Investigations revealed the following as shown below. The peripheral smear is shown below. What is the diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

Hb – 5 g%

 

MCH – 24

 

MCV – Low

 

TLC – 11000 /µL

 

Platelets – 5,00,000 /cubic mm

 

Normal values:

 

  • Mean cell volume (MCV): 90 +/- 8 fL
  • Mean cell Hb (MCH): 30 +/- 3 pg
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Iron-deficiency anemia

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of microcytic hypochromic anemia for which the most common cause is Iron Deficiency Anemia.

 

Iron deficiency anemia is characterized by:

 

  • Low serum ferritin: Reflects low iron stores.
  • Low serum iron: Indicates a lack of available iron.
  • High TIBC (Total Iron Binding Capacity): Reflects the body’s increased capacity to bind iron, which happens when iron levels are low.
  • Low transferrin saturation: Reflects low iron availability relative to the binding capacity.

 

These findings together with the low MCV, low MCH, low Hb and compensatory increase in the platelets strongly suggest iron deficiency anemia rather than other conditions.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Megaloblastic anemia: Typically presents with macrocytic anemia (high MCV), which is not the case here. Also, MCH would generally be elevated in megaloblastic anemia.

 

Option C. Thalassemia major: This condition would also present with microcytic anemia, but it typically does not show such severe hypochromia or the thrombocytosis seen in this case. Additionally, the Mentzer index (MCV/RBC count) is typically less than 13 in thalassemia trait, not in severe iron deficiency anemia.

 

Option D. Essential thrombocytosis: While this condition does present with an elevated platelet count, it does not typically present with the microcytic, hypochromic anemia seen in iron deficiency anemia. The primary abnormality in essential thrombocytosis is the elevated platelet count, without the severe anemia observed here.

 

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Acute HBV infection in window period
HBV infection in the remote past, completely recovered

questions.text:
The blood investigation of a patient is given below. What is the probable diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2023)

 

  • HBsAg - NR,
  • Anti HBs - NR,
  • Anti HBc IgM - NR,
  • Anti HBc total - positive,
  • HBeAg - NR,
  • Anti HBe – NR (NR – Non reactive)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HBV infection in the remote past, completely recovered

 

Explanation:  

 

The patient's serological markers indicate the following:

 

  • HBsAg - Non-Reactive (NR): This suggests that the patient is not currently infected with Hepatitis B.

 

  • Anti HBs - NR: Lack of antibodies against the Hepatitis B surface antigen suggests no current immunity from vaccination or recent infection.

 

  • Anti HBc IgM - NR: The absence of IgM antibodies against the core antigen indicates no recent acute infection.
  • Anti HBc total - positive: Presence of total core antibodies (including IgG) indicates past exposure to the virus.

 

  • HBeAg - NR: Absence of the e antigen suggests no active viral replication.

 

  • Anti HBe - NR: Absence of antibodies against the e antigen suggests no current or recent active infection.

 

Given these markers, the most likely scenario is that the patient had a Hepatitis B infection in the past and has completely recovered. The presence of Anti HBc total (which is predominantly IgG) signifies past infection. In cases of remote past infection, anti-HBs antibodies may fall below detectable levels, although the patient still has immunity through memory B cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute HBV infection in window period: In the window period of acute HBV infection, Anti HBc IgM should be positive, which is not the case here.

 

Option B. Immune with recombinant HBV Vaccine: Patients vaccinated against HBV typically have positive Anti HBs and negative Anti HBc total, as they have not been exposed to the virus.

 

Option D. Chronic HBV infection inactive carrier: Chronic HBV infection requires the presence of HBsAg for more than six months. The absence of HBsAg rules out chronic infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Anti HBc total (predominantly IgG) with all other markers negative suggests a past HBV infection that has completely resolved.

questions.text: The presence of a pearly white papule on the mother's forehead, which is also seen in her infant, can be due to which of the following virus? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pox virus

 

The above image shows shiny, pearly white, umbilicated papules which are suggestive of molluscum contagiosum. It’s a DNA virus.

 

  • It is mainly caused by Pox virus which is a DNA virus.
  • Virus: Molluscum Contagiosum Virus (MCV).
    • MCV-1: Children over Face (Not seen over palms & soles).
    • MCV-2: Adults producing lesions over Genitals.
  • Microscopic examination - Lesions shows eosinophilic inclusions called Henderson-Patterson bodies.
  • Transmission: Skin to skin contact.

 

Note: Sexually transmitted molluscum contagiosum may be present over the genital area.

 

Treatment:

 

  • Usually, it is self-limiting and will disappear by itself. Thus, there is no need for treatment.
  • Destruction with cantharidin, trichloroacetic acid, diluted liquefied phenol, or surgical removal are a few options.

 

Pseudo-Koebner phenomenon: New lesions develop along the line of trauma due to Autoinoculation.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. HPV (Human Papilloma Virus) leads to warts, but the lesions are typically rough-surfaced as shown in the image below, rather than pearly.

 

 

  • Option C. Adenovirus does not typically cause visible skin manifestations like the one shown.
  • Option D. Herpes virus causes vesicular and ulcerative lesions as shown in the image below, rather than pearly papules.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of pearly white papules in both a mother and her infant is indicative of molluscum contagiosum, a skin infection caused by a Poxvirus.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I, Chapter 25, Page no 25.12-14

choices.text: 1-A, 2-B, 3-C, 4-D
1-D, 2-F, 3-E, 4-C
1-D, 2-A, 3-C 4-E
1-D, 2-C, 3-F, 4-E

questions.text: Match the following drugs with their ocular adverse effects?(AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 1-D, 2-C, 3-F, 4-E

 

The following are the drugs and their associated ocular adverse effects:

 

  1. Amiodarone: This drug is known to cause corneal deposits (cornea verticillata) and optic neuritis. The correct match for Amiodarone is D (Optic neuritis).
  2. Hydroxychloroquine: This drug is associated with bull’s eye maculopathy, a specific type of retinopathy. Therefore, Hydroxychloroquine is correctly matched with C (Retinopathy).
  3. Systemic steroids: When given topically, systemic steroids can cause open-angle glaucoma. However, when given systemically, they are known to cause posterior subcapsular cataract. Thus, systemic steroids are best matched with F (Cataract).
  4. Digoxin: This drug can cause yellow vision, a condition where the patient perceives a yellow tint in their vision. Hence, Digoxin is correctly matched with E (Yellow vision).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ocular adverse-effects of drugs:

 

  • Amiodarone: Corneal deposits (cornea verticallata) Optic neuritis
  • Hydroxychloroquine: Bull’s eye maculopathy (retinopathy).
  • Systemic steroids: Given topically – cause Open angle Glaucoma; Given systemically – cause Posterior subcapsular cataract.
  • Digoxin: Yellow vision

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/880, 318, 560, Goodman Gilman 13th/  564

questions.text: Which of the following given cancers rarely metastasize to the liver? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Prostate

 

Prostate Cancers rarely metastasize to the liver.

 

Prostate cancer tends to metastasize to bones via periprostatic venous plexus (Bateson) rather than the liver. Bone metastases are a hallmark of advanced prostate cancer. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Colon: Colon cancer commonly metastasizes to the liver. The liver is one of the most common sites of metastasis for colon cancer, and it frequently spreads to the liver through the bloodstream.

 

Option B. Breast: Breast cancer can metastasize to various organs, including the liver. Liver metastases in breast cancer are not uncommon, and the liver is considered a potential site of spread for breast cancer cells.

 

Option D. Melanoma: Melanoma is known for its propensity to metastasize to various organs, including the liver. Liver metastases are common in advanced melanoma cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common malignant tumors of the liver are metastasis. The liver is a common site of metastases from gastrointestinal tumors because of dissemination via the portal venous system. The most relevant such metastatic tumor of the liver to the surgeon is colorectal cancer because of the well-documented potential for long-term survival after its complete resection.

 

The more frequent primary sites include carcinomas of the colon, pancreas, lung, and breast in adults, and neuroblastoma, Wilms tumor, and rhabdomyosarcoma in pediatric patients. Although the origin of the tumor is often known when metastases are biopsied, carcinomas of the pancreas, stomach, and lung are particularly notorious for being occult primary neoplasms.

questions.text:
Which of the following is the best investigation for aneuploidy? (INICET NOV 2024)

 

  1. In Situ Hybridization
  2. Conventional cytogenetics 
  3. PCR
  4. Sanger sequencing
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A & B

 

For the detection of aneuploidy, both In Situ Hybridization (specifically FISH - Fluorescent In Situ Hybridization) and conventional cytogenetics are the best investigations. "FISH technique is an important technique which not only helps to detect the presence of microdeletions or an excess number of certain types of genes being expressed it also helps to detect the presence of specific chromosomal translocations.

 

Conventional cytogenetics, though more time-consuming than FISH, is still an effective method for aneuploidy detection. It involves visualizing the chromosomes under a microscope during cell division to count them and look for gross abnormalities.

 

Both techniques allow direct visualization of chromosomal material and can detect numerical abnormalities like aneuploidy. FISH is particularly valuable because it can rapidly detect common aneuploidies like trisomy 21, 18, 13 within 24-48 hours.

 

Other Options:

 

Option C & D (PCR and Sanger sequencing): These techniques are not the best for detecting aneuploidy. PCR and Sanger sequencing are used for analyzing specific DNA sequences and mutations, but they cannot effectively detect changes in chromosome number.

 

Educational Objective:

 

FISH (Fluorescent In Situ Hybridization) and conventional cytogenetics are the best techniques for detecting aneuploidy (abnormal chromosome numbers), while PCR and Sanger sequencing are used for specific sequence analysis but not aneuploidy detection.

choices.text: 20.8 hours
6.9 hours
13.8 hours

questions.text: The elimination rate constant of a drug is 0.05 hr. What is its half-life? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 13.8 hours

 

  • Half-life is the time in which the plasma concentration of the drug becomes half.
  • The elimination rate constant of a drug reflects the fraction of drug that is removed from the body compartment per unit time.
  • The elimination rate constant = k = 0.05 hr.
  • Half-life = t1/2 = 0.693/k
  • Therefore t1/2 = 0.693/0.05 =13.8 hrs.
     

Educational Objective:

 

The half-life of a drug with an elimination rate constant of 0.05 hr is 13.8 hours, calculated using the formula t1/2=0.693/k

questions.text: In which of the following conditions do you see punched-out lesions of the retina? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Toxoplasmosis

 

Toxoplasmosis is a parasitic infection caused by Toxoplasma gondii that affects the central nervous system and retina in humans.

 

It can occur as 3 forms:

 

  1. Congenital: infants are typically born with inactive disease, and doctors may observe healed punched-out chorioretinal lesions in the macular region.
  2. Acquired: can also result in similar punched-out lesions, along with punctate outer retinal toxoplasmosis.
  3. Recurrent Toxoplasmosis: Patients may experience multiple episodes of retinal inflammation, leading to further accumulation of these punched-out lesions over time.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Posterior staphyloma: This refers to an outpouching or deformation of the posterior shell of the eye, often associated with severe myopia but not characterized by punched-out lesions.

 

Option B. Fundal coloboma: A congenital malformation resulting in missing pieces of tissue in structures forming the eye, such as the choroid and retina, which does not typically present as punched-out lesions.

 

Option C. Congenital rubella: While it can cause retinal changes, the signature features often include salt and pepper retinopathy rather than punched-out lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The appearance of punched-out lesions in the retina is crucial for diagnosing toxoplasmosis. This understanding can aid in distinguishing toxoplasmosis from other infectious or congenital conditions that affect the retina, guiding appropriate diagnostic and therapeutic interventions.

questions.text: The transmission of infection during the perinatal period exhibits a range of symptoms, including anemia, potential myocarditis, high-output cardiac failure, and ascites. Identify the specific causative agent responsible for these manifestations: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Parvovirus B19

 

  • The provided clinical scenario presents a patient with symptoms of anemia, myocarditis, high output cardiac failure, and ascites, along with an accompanying image displaying hydrops fetalis.
  • These manifestations collectively suggest a diagnosis of erythema infectiosum, commonly known as Fifth disease, which is caused by parvovirus B19.

 

MANIFESTATIONS OF PARVOVIRUS B19

 

1. Fetus

 

  • Severe anemia (transient aplastic crises)
  • Pure red cell aplasia
  • Congestive heart failure
  • Hydrops fetalis
  • Spontaneous abortion

 

 

2. Children/adults

 

  • Fifth disease, erythema infectiosum, slapped cheek fever
  • 7−10-day incubation
  • Nonspecific “flu-like” symptoms followed by raised, indurated facial rash (Slapped cheek)

 

 

3. Adults

 

  • Rash and arthralgias (involves wrist most often) are due to immune complexes in the skin and joints.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Treponema pallidum (Syphilis) in pregnancy leads to subsequent pregnancy loss.

 

Option B. CMV (Cytomegalovirus) by trans placental spread causes fetal damage at all gestational ages. Features are periventricular calcifications, microcephaly, hearing loss, hydrops fetalis.

 

Option D. Toxoplasma gondii intracerebral calcifications, hydrocephalus, chorioretinitis.

 

Educational Objective

 

Parvovirus B19 is responsible for severe anemia, hydrops fetalis, and other serious complications in fetuses.

questions.text: In which of the following is atropine contraindicated? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acute congestive glaucoma

 

The use of atropine is not recommended in cases of acute congestive or angle closure glaucoma due to the risk of increasing intraocular pressure.

 

  • Since atropine is a mydriatic, it may lead to the obstruction of the trabecular meshwork by the peripheral iris, causing a sudden increase in intraocular pressure.
  • Dim light can also precipitate an attack.
    • Atropine may be indicated as a cycloplegic agent to alleviate pain and prevent synechiae formation in corneal ulcers and acute anterior uveitis.
    • In malignant glaucoma, atropine can be the initial management option.
    • In corneal ulcers, atropine is used as an adjuvant therapy, to reduce pain induced by ciliary muscle spasm via its cycloplegic effect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acute anterior uveitis: Atropine is actually beneficial in cases of acute anterior uveitis. It helps to relieve pain by paralyzing the ciliary muscle and preventing the formation of posterior synechiae (adhesions between the iris and the lens), which can complicate uveitis.

 

Option C. Malignant glaucoma: In malignant glaucoma, atropine might be used as part of the management strategy to try to break the attack by deepening the anterior chamber and pulling the lens-iris diaphragm backward.

 

Option D. Corneal ulcer: Atropine is used in the treatment of corneal ulcers to provide comfort by relieving the painful ciliary spasm and to prevent synechiae.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atropine should be used cautiously, and is contraindicated in acute congestive glaucoma due to its potential to exacerbate the condition by further increasing intraocular pressure.

questions.text: Which part of 2nd metatarsal is involved in the march fracture?(AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neck

 

MARCH FRACTURE

 

  • March fracture is a stress fatigue fracture of second metatarsal neck > 3rd metatarsal neck.
  • The second metatarsal is more prone to injury due to its limited motion from strong ligamentous attachment to the first and second cuneiforms and length compared to the other foot metatarsals.
  • They result from a sudden increase in the intensity, duration, and frequency of activity without sufficient rest.
  • The repetitive impact on the metatarsals with weight-bearing exercises causes microfractures, which consolidate into stress fractures and are not the result of a single traumatic event.

 

 

  • Common Fracture Eponyms:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The march fracture involves the neck of the 2nd metatarsal followed by 3rd metatarsal.
  • It is a stress fracture of the metatarsal.

questions.text: In the 2 vessels shown below, assume the pressure along both the vessels is the same and both follow linear flow pattern. What will be the amount of blood flow in A compared to B? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 8 times

 

According to Poiseuille's law:

 

 

in which F is the rate of blood flow, ∆P is the pressure difference between the ends of the vessel, r is the radius of the vessel, l is length of the vessel, and h is viscosity of the blood.

 

Therefore, blood flow (F) inside the vessel is

 

  • ﻿﻿Directly proportional to the pressure difference
  • ﻿﻿Inversely proportional to the viscosity:
  • ﻿﻿Directly proportional to the fourth power of radius
  • ﻿﻿Inversely proportional to length of the vessel

 

So, if the radius is doubled flow will increase by 2 to the power of 4 = 16

And if the length of the vessel is also doubled, the reduces by half (÷2) = 8

 

Educational Objective:

 

According to Poiseuille's law blood flow (𝐹F) is:

 

  • Directly proportional to the pressure difference (Δ𝑃ΔP)
  • Inversely proportional to the viscosity (𝜂η)
  • Directly proportional to the fourth power of the radius (𝑟4r4)
  • Inversely proportional to the length of the vessel (𝑙l)

choices.text: Sensory level is from T10 to L1
Uterine contractility is mediated by innervations from level T7 - T8
In the 1st stage of labor, pain is due to the fibers at level of T10 - L1
In early labor, pain is usually because of the uterine contraction

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding innervation of the uterus? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Uterine contractility is mediated by innervations from level T7 - T8

 

Explanation:

 

The incorrect statement regarding the innervation of the uterus is option B. Uterine contractility is primarily mediated by hormonal mechanisms rather than by specific spinal innervations. Hormones such as estrogen, prostaglandins, and oxytocin play a significant role in inducing uterine contractions, while progesterone helps maintain uterine relaxation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sensory level is from T10 to L1: The sensory innervation of the uterus is indeed from spinal levels T10 to L1. These afferent fibers enter the spinal cord via the inferior hypogastric plexus and are responsible for transmitting sensory information from the uterus.

 

Option C. In the 1st stage of labor, pain is due to the fibers at level of T10 - L1: During the 1st stage of labor, pain is mediated by spinal segments T10 to L1. This pain is due to the distension of the cervix and lower uterine segment, as well as the contraction of the uterus.

 

Option D. In early labor, pain is usually because of the uterine contraction: In early labor, pain is usually related to uterine contractions, which stimulate nociceptors in the genital tract and can cause discomfort and pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Uterine contractility is not mediated by innervations from spinal level T7 - T8; instead, it is primarily influenced by hormonal mechanisms.

 

 

Ref: Page 500, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

questions.text: Abrupt stoppage of which of the following drugs causes agitation, anxiety and insomnia? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Venlafaxine

 

Abrupt discontinuation or dose reduction of venlafaxine has been known to result in a discontinuation syndrome characterized by agitation, anxiety, and insomnia. This is particularly noted with venlafaxine because of its short half-life. While all the drugs listed can have withdrawal symptoms if stopped suddenly, venlafaxine is particularly associated with these symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Valproate: Abrupt discontinuation can lead to seizure recurrence in those using it as an antiepileptic and can cause relapse of mood symptoms in those using it as mood stabilizer.

 

Option B. Olanzapine: Stopping it can result in a return of psychotic symptoms.

 

Option C. Imipramine: It can cause withdrawal symptoms, but they are typically more varied and might include headache, nausea, and malaise.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The key features of antidepressant discontinuation syndrome, often abbreviated as FINISH:

 

  • Flu-like symptoms
  • Insomnia
  • Nausea
  • Imbalance
  • Sensory disturbances (e.g., electric shock sensations)
  • Hyperarousal (e.g., anxiety, agitation).

 

It is particularly common with SSRIs and SNRIs with shorter half-lives, such as venlafaxine (most common). Short acting SSRIs such as paroxetine and fluvoxamine are also commonly associated with discontinuation syndrome. Gradual tapering and patient education are essential to prevent and manage this syndrome.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry, 10th edition, Page No 3150.

questions.text: During rounds, your senior was discussing the given image. The following is an image of which of the following investigations? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. CT scan

 

Explanation:  

 

The above given image is a CT scan image since the bone can be identified as a high-density structure which appears white.

 

CT scan is an imaging modality which uses X-rays for cross sectional images of the body and the density of the tissue through which this x-ray beam passes is measured from the calculation of attenuation coefficient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Contrast Dye study: While contrast may be used in CT scans, the term "contrast dye study" alone does not specifically indicate a CT scan.

 

Option B. X-ray: Typically provides two-dimensional imaging and lacks the cross-sectional detail shown in these images.

 

Option C. D Angiography: Focuses on blood vessels using contrast material and typically does not provide detailed images of other anatomical structures as seen in these scans.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CT scans are invaluable in medical imaging for providing detailed cross-sectional views of internal structures, utilizing X-ray technology to distinguish between different tissue densities, evident from the white appearance of bone and detailed soft tissue visualization in the images.

questions.text: What is absent in a case of otitis media among the options provided? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Battle's sign

 

Battle's sign, characterized by ecchymosis (bruising) over the mastoid process, is typically indicative of a basilar skull fracture, specifically fractures involving the temporal bone. It is not associated with otitis media, which is an infection or inflammation of the middle ear.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bezold abscess: This abscess is a serious complication of otitis media. It occurs when the infection spreads from the mastoid process into the surrounding tissues, leading to a collection of pus.

Option B. Griesinger's sign: This sign is associated with lateral sinus thrombosis, a rare but severe complication of otitis media and mastoiditis. It involves tenderness and swelling behind the ear and along the mastoid bone.

Option D. Delta sign: Also related to lateral sinus thrombosis, the Delta sign typically appears on contrast-enhanced imaging studies as a NON enhancement at thrombosed area of sinus, a complication arising from otitis media.

Educational Objective:

 

While otitis media can lead to various complications, including Bezold abscess and lateral sinus thrombosis (indicated by Griesinger’s sign and Delta sign), Battle's sign is not associated with this condition. Instead, Battle's sign should prompt an evaluation for temporal bone fractures, emphasizing the importance of distinguishing between signs of infection and trauma.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 87, 93, 507

questions.text: What does the given image represent?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hypnogram

 

Image is showing a graphical representation of the stages of sleep over time, which is seen in Hypnogram.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Electroencephalogram (EEG): A graphical representation of electrical activity in the brain. The tracing typically displays waveforms such as alpha, beta, delta, and theta waves.

 

Option C. Polysomnogram: A comprehensive recording used during a sleep study that includes an EEG (brain activity), as well as eye movements, muscle activity, heart rate, respiratory effort, air flow, and blood oxygen levels.

 

Option D. Epworth Sleep Assessment: It's not a graph or image; it's a questionnaire used to determine the level of daytime sleepiness.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Hypnogram is a graphical representation of the stages of sleep over time, usually throughout a night.

 

Reference: Textbook of Psychiatry by Allan Tasman, 4th edition, Page No 1271.

questions.text:
A hypertensive patient on medication presents with the following lab values:


K⁺: 6.5 meq/L


Na⁺: 137 meq/L


Urea: 42 mg/dL


Creatinine: 3.8 mg/dL


Which of the following drugs should be stopped?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Losartan


In this hypertensive patient with hyperkalemia, losartan must be stopped.

 

Losartan is a competitive angiotensin II (AT1) receptor antagonist, which binds to the AT1 receptor with high affinity. Uses of losartan include:

 

  • Antihypertensive
  • Renoprotective drug in diabetes mellitus
  • Stroke prophylaxis
  • Portal hypertension in cirrhosis without compromising renal function
  • Anti-aggregant as it is a competitive antagonist of the thromboxane A2 receptor.

 

Hyperkalemia is an important side effect of ARBs. Losartan appears to be a safe and efficacious agent to lower serum uric acid levels in patients with hyperuricemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amlodipine: Gingival hyperplasia and ankle swelling are side effects of calcium channel blockers like amlodipine. Ankle edema occurs due to increased hydrostatic pressure in the capillaries present in the dependent parts of the body. This is due to reflex constriction of postcapillary vessels. Other common side effects of amlodipine include headache, dizziness, and abdominal pain.

 

Option B. Metoprolol: Metoprolol is a cardioselective beta-blocker. Cardioselective beta-blockers are less likely to cause hyperkalemia as an adverse effect. The risk of metoprolol-induced hyperkalemia is increased if the patient is also diabetic.

 

Option D. Furosemide: Furosemide is a loop diuretic. It acts by inhibiting the Na⁺-K⁺-2Cl⁻ symporter in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle, resulting in increased excretion of sodium, potassium, and chloride. Hypokalemia, hyperuricemia, hypocalcemia, and hypomagnesemia are the important side effects.

 

Educational Objective:


Losartan, an ARB (angiotensin receptor blocker), should be discontinued in hypertensive patients with hyperkalemia as it can worsen potassium retention.

choices.text: Difference in alveolar pressure during inspiration and expiration
Difference in concentration of surfactant during inspiration and expiration
Difference in airway resistance during inspiration and expiration
Inspiration is active and expiration is passive

questions.text: Difference in trajectory between inspiratory loop and the expiratory loop in the curve is due to: (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Difference in concentration of surfactant during inspiration and expiration

 

The above shows the compliance diagram of lung

 

Compliance Diagram of the Lungs

 

It is a diagram relating lung volume changes to changes in transpulmonary pressure. 

 

The characteristics of the compliance diagram are determined

 

The surfactant, secreted by type II pneumocytes, reduces surface tension in alveoli.


During inspiration, alveoli expand, decreasing the surfactant concentration, which leads to increased surface tension, requiring more pressure to keep alveoli open.


During expiration, alveoli deflate, increasing surfactant concentration, thus decreasing surface tension, and requiring less pressure.


This asymmetry in surface tension during inspiration and expiration contributes to the difference in the trajectory (hysteresis) of the curve
 

The tissue elastic forces tending to cause collapse of the air-filled lung represent only about one third of the total lung elasticity, whereas the fluid-air surface tension forces in the alveoli represent about two thirds.

 

Thus, a greater transpulmonary pressure is required to open a previously closed airway due to surface tension at the air-water interface due to surfactant deficit, than to keep an open airway from closing, reflecting abundant surfactant.

 

 

 

Surfactant concentration increases during expiration (smaller alveoli → surfactant molecules closer), lowering surface tension and making expiration easier compared to inspiration. This is the correct cause of hysteresis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Difference in alveolar pressure during inspiration and expiration: Incorrect, as this refers to the pressure gradients that drive airflow but does not directly cause the loop shape differences seen in the compliance graph.

 

Option C. Airway resistance can be higher during expiration due to dynamic airway compression, especially in obstructive diseases.

However, the P-V loop is a static curve, plotted during slow, controlled breathing or when airflow has ceased — not during forced maneuvers — so airway resistance has minimal impact on this loop. This might be more relevant to flow-volume loops, not pressure-volume loops

 

Option D. This is true physiologically — inspiration involves active muscle contraction, and expiration is usually passive at rest. But this does not explain the hysteresis in the pressure-volume loop.  The loop reflects lung compliance and surface tension, not the energy used for breathing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The difference between inspiratory and expiratory pressure-volume loops (hysteresis) is primarily due to dynamic changes in surfactant concentration, which alters surface tension between inspiration and expiration. Understanding this helps explain lung compliance behavior and the role of surfactant in stabilizing alveoli.

choices.text: It is the main restraint in posterior drawer test
It is an extrasynovial structure
It is the main restraint to internal rotation
It originates from anterolateral aspect of medial femoral condyle in the area of intercondylar notch

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about PCL? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. It is the main restraint to internal rotation

 

LIGAMENT INJURIES OF THE KNEE JOINT

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • PCL is the an extrasynovial structure originating from the anterolateral aspect of the medial femoral condyle in the area of intercondylar notch.
  • It is the main restraint to the posterior translation of the knee i.e., the backward gliding of the tibia over the femur.
  • While evaluating the patient during physical examination, PCL is the main restraint in the posterior drawer test.

choices.text: Call the infection control team of the hospital

questions.text: You're an intern in a bustling hospital laboratory. As you're overseeing the day's activities, you notice that a newly appointed technician accidentally spills a blood sample on the floor. The technician, looking panicked, turns to you for guidance. Given the potential risks associated with blood spills, what is the most immediate and appropriate action you should instruct the technician to take? [AIIMS NOV 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Clean with absorbable material

 

  • In this situation, the next crucial action to take is to utilize absorbent material for cleaning up the spilled blood. Once the cleaning is complete, the used absorbent material should be disposed of in the designated yellow bin. Subsequently, a sodium hypochlorite solution is employed to thoroughly decontaminate the affected surface. The specific concentrations of sodium hypochlorite employed are as follows:
    • < 10 mL blood spill - 1:100 dilution to decontaminate non-porous surfaces
    • >10 mL blood spill or culture spill - 1:10 dilution for the first application, followed by 1:100 dilution

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Call the infection control team of the hospital: While important, this is not the immediate action to take to contain the spill.

 

Option B. Mop it: Mopping without proper absorbent material and decontamination procedures could spread the contamination.

 

Option C. Cover it with 1% sodium hypochlorite: This step should follow the initial clean-up with absorbent material to ensure thorough decontamination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypochlorites in Hospital waste Management

 

  • Disinfection of countertops and floors
  • Decontamination of blood spills
  • Irrigating agent in endodontic treatment
  • Disinfectant for manikins, laundry, dental appliances, hydrotherapy tanks
  • Treatment of liquid medical waste before disposal
  • Decontaminating water distribution systems in dialysis

questions.text: Duration of action of Proparacaine? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 20 mins

 

Proparacaine:

 

  • Duration of Action: The duration of action of proparacaine is approximately 15-20 minutes.
  • Uses: Proparacaine hydrochloride is used as a topical anesthetic agent, especially for ophthalmic surgeries such as:
    • Tonometry
    • Gonioscopy
    • Removal of corneal foreign bodies
    • Short corneal and conjunctival procedures

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The duration of action of proparacaine is approximately 15-20 minutes, making it suitable for short ophthalmic procedures.

choices.text: Buffy coat is used to diagnose the parasite
It is an obligate extracellular parasite
Stibogluconate is the first line of treatment in India

questions.text: Bone marrow aspirate of a patient shows the following features. Which of the following is true? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Buffy coat is used to diagnose the parasite

 

The given image shows the amastigote form of leishmaniasis located intracellularly in macrophages. Buffy coat is used to diagnose the parasite.

 

Buffy coat is the portion of blood that contains concentrates of white blood cells, including monocytes and platelets, and for obvious reasons its smear can be examined for detection of L. donovani bodies in suspected VL patients.

 

Detection of Leishmania donovani bodies in peripheral blood buffy coat smears is an alternative and minimally invasive procedure for the parasitological diagnosis of VL.

 

PCR assay with buffy coat preparations to detect Leishmania DNA has been found to be 10 times more sensitive than that with whole-blood preparation.

 

Serodiagnosis is a valid and the detection in serum and urine specimens of antileishmanial antibody against recombinant antigens such as rK39 by rapid immunochromatographic tests

 

Aldehyde test of Napier: Widely used for surveillance.

 

Serological tests for diagnosis: Rapid dipstick test, Direct agglutination test, ELISA, Indirect Fluorescent Antibody Test

 

Leishmanin (Montenegro) test: Induration of 5mm or more is considered positive, usually positive 4-6 weeks after onset in cutaneous leishmaniasis, valuable for distinguishing immune from nonimmune subjects and endemicity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It is an obligate extracellular parasite: This is incorrect. Leishmania donovani is an intracellular parasite that resides within macrophages.

 

Option C. It is transmitted from sheep: This is incorrect. Leishmania is transmitted by the bite of infected female phlebotomine sandflies, not by sheep.

 

Option D. Stibogluconate is the first line of treatment in India: This is partially outdated. Sodium stibogluconate was once the first line of treatment, but now liposomal amphotericin B and miltefosine are commonly used as first-line treatments in India due to increased resistance to antimonials.

 

Educational Objective:


Buffy coat is used to diagnose Leishmania donovani by detecting the amastigote form in intracellular macrophages in patients with visceral leishmaniasis.

choices.text: Maternal Deaths per 10,000 women in reproductive age group
Maternal Deaths per 100,000 women in reproductive age group

questions.text: Dr. Aishwarya, a public health official, is discussing the maternal health situation in a rural district of Uttar Pradesh at a Panchayat meeting. She emphasizes the importance of understanding the maternal mortality ratio (MMR) for her district. Which definition best describes the MMR? [AIIMS MAY 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Maternal Deaths per 100,000 live births 

 

  • MMR is Maternal deaths expressed as per 100,000 live births.
  • Maternal Mortality rate (MMR): Maternal deaths expressed as per 100,000 live births, where a ‘maternal death’ is defined as ‘death of a woman while pregnant or during delivery or within 42 days (6 weeks) of termination of pregnancy, irrespective of duration or site of pregnancy, from any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management but not from accidental or incidental causes’.
  • MMR is a ratio (Maternal mortality rate is a misnomer; MMR is not a rate)

 

 

Additional Information

 

  • MMR World: 216 per 100,000 live births; Causes of MMR (globally):
    • Hemorrhage (25%)
    • Indirect causes (20%)
    • Infection (15%)
    • Unsafe abortion (13%)
    • Eclampsia (12%)
    • Obstructed labour (8%)
  • MMR India: 97 per 100,000 live births [2023]; Causes of MMR (India) [SRS 2023]:
    • Hemorrhage (38%)
    • Other conditions (34%)
    • Sepsis (11%)
    • Abortion (8%)
    • Obstructed labour (5%)
    • Hypertensive disorders (5%)
  • Maternal mortality rate (MMRate): Dividing the average annual number of maternal deaths in a population by the average number of women of reproductive age (typically those aged 15 to 49 years) who are alive during the observation period. 

 

MMRate reflects not only the risk of maternal death per pregnancy or per birth, but also the level of fertility in a population

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • MMR is a crucial indicator of maternal health in a population, reflecting the risk of maternal death associated with childbirth and its management.
  • It is typically expressed per 100,000 live births to provide a clear picture of maternal health risks and the effectiveness of health interventions aimed at reducing these risks in specific areas or populations.

choices.text: Laparoscopic tubal ligation

questions.text: Which of the following is an irreversible method of contraception? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Laparoscopic tubal ligation

 

Contraceptive methods can be classified into temporary (reversible) and permanent (irreversible) methods.

 

  • Permanent Methods (Irreversible):
    • Laparoscopic Tubal Ligation: This is a surgical procedure where the fallopian tubes are cut, tied, or sealed to prevent pregnancy permanently. It is considered an irreversible method of contraception as it is intended to be a permanent solution for women who do not wish to have more children.
  • Temporary Methods (Reversible):
    • Copper-T (Intrauterine Device - IUD): A long-term but reversible method that can be removed when pregnancy is desired.
    • Implanon (Subdermal Contraceptive Implant): A long-term reversible method that can be removed to restore fertility.
    • LNG-IUD (Levonorgestrel Intrauterine Device): Another long-term reversible method that can be removed when pregnancy is desired.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laparoscopic tubal ligation is a permanent (irreversible) method of contraception.

 

Ref: Page no 611, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presented with burns injury. She is covered with burns on her head and neck, both upper limbs, front and back of the chest. Calculate the percentage of burns? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 45%

 

To calculate the percentage of burns, the "Rule of Nines" is commonly used in medicine. According to this rule, each area of the body is assigned a percentage value.

 

For example, the head and neck are typically assigned 9%, each upper limb is assigned 9% (18% total for both), and the front and back of the chest are assigned 18%. When we add these percentages together, we get a total of 45% burns.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The percentage of burns calculated in the given patient is 45% according to Wallace's rule of nine.

 

Calculation:

 

  • Burns on the head & neck would account for 9% of burns.
  • Burns on both upper limbs (9% for each limb) would add to 18%
  • Burns on both sides of the chest would account for 18%

Therefore, the total percentage of burns in the given patient is 9+18+18 = 45%

 

Wallace's rule of nine:

questions.text: A young patient presented with hypoparathyroidism, absent thymus and tetany. Which of the following marked areas in the picture is defective in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 12

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical scenario of hypoparathyroidism, absent thymus, and tetany is suggestive of DiGeorge syndrome. It is caused by defective development of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouch.

 

In the image of pharyngeal pouches, "12" points to the thymus (derivative of 3rd pharyngeal pouch). Since in the above question, the thymus is absent, option 3 will be the most appropriate answer.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. (1): 1st Pharyngeal pouches, which is unrelated to the thymus or parathyroid glands directly involved in this case.

 

Option B. (10): External auditory meatus, which is not implicated in DiGeorge syndrome.

 

Option D. (13): Superior parathyroid gland, derived from the fourth pharyngeal pouch. Although it's closely related to the condition described, the primary indicator in this scenario, given the patient's symptoms, is the thymus rather than the parathyroid glands.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DiGeorge syndrome, also known as 22q11.2 deletion syndrome, is a genetic disorder caused by a missing piece of chromosome 22. It is characterized by a wide range of symptoms that can vary in severity, but are typically grouped together as mnemonic CATCH -22

 

Mnemonic "CATCH-22":

 

C - Cardiac abnormalities, such as ventricular septal defects (VSD) and tetralogy of Fallot.

 

A - Abnormal facies, including a small chin, low-set ears, and wide-set eyes.

 

T - Thymic aplasia or hypoplasia, leading to a weakened immune system.

 

C - Cleft palate or other palate abnormalities.

 

H - Hypocalcemia or low levels of calcium due to underdeveloped or missing parathyroid glands.

 

22 - Refers to the chromosome 22q11.2 deletion, which causes the syndrome.
